question_text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient treated with an antipsychotic medication, select the most likely diagnosis.
A) Tardive dyskinesia
B) Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
C) Akathisia
D) Acute dystonia
E) Pseudoparkinsonism
F) Tourette syndrome
G) Serotonin syndrome
H) Huntington disease
I) Restless legs syndrome
A 60-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of involuntary movements of the tongue and face that started 2 days ago. She has schizophrenia that has been controlled with haloperidol decanoate for the past 18 months. She lives in an assisted-living facility. She does not drink alcohol but has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 138/75 mm Hg. Examination shows protrusion of the tongue and slow, rhythmic perioral movements. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Treatment with benztropine is begun. One week later, her symptoms have worsened.
content_preview: The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set. For each patient treated with an antipsychotic medication, select the most likely diagnosis. A) Tardive dyskinesia B) Neuroleptic malignant syndrome C) Akathisia D) Acute dystonia E) Pseudoparkinsonism F) Tourette syndrome G) Serotonin syndrome H) Huntington disease I) Restless legs syndrome A 60-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of involuntary movements of the tongue and face that started 2 days ago. She has schizophrenia that has been controlled with haloperidol decanoate for the past 18 months. She lives in an assisted-living facility. She does not drink alcohol but has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 138/75 mm Hg. Examination shows protrusion of the tongue and slow, rhythmic perioral movements. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Treatment with benztropine is begun. One week later, her symptoms have worsened.
hint: This patient's current condition is often irreversible.
learning_objective: Distinguish tardive dyskinesia from other causes of involuntary movements.

answers.explanation_why: Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary movements of the tongue and mouth, as seen in this patient, that manifest within months to years following the administration of dopamine-blocking agents. The annual risk of developing TD from first-generation antipsychotic use is up to 25% among older adults while the annual risk associated with second-generation antipsychotic use is ∼ 5%. Symptoms often persist despite discontinuation of the offending drug. Vesicular monoamine transporter-2 inhibitors (e.g., valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) can be used to treat moderate to severe TD. Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) can exacerbate symptoms, as seen in this patient.

images.title: Timeline of extrapyramidal symptoms induced by antipsychotics

answers.explanation_why: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a life-threatening condition that can develop within the first 2 weeks following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol). This condition is characterized by hyperthermia, muscular rigidity, autonomic instability, and mental status changes; it does not cause involuntary movements of the tongue and face.

Akathisia is a movement disorder that can manifest following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol). However, it usually develops within the first 1–8 weeks after initiation of therapy. In addition, this condition is characterized by motor restlessness (i.e., a compelling urge to move), which can manifest with an inability to sit or stand still; it does not cause involuntary movements of the tongue and face. Moreover, this condition typically improves with benztropine therapy.

Acute dystonia is an adverse effect of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol) that can manifest with protrusion of the tongue. However, this adverse effect usually manifests within hours to days after initiation of therapy. In addition, it typically also causes painful, lasting muscle spasms that most commonly affect the head and neck, which this patient does not have. Moreover, acute dystonia typically improves with benztropine therapy.

Pseudoparkinsonism can develop days to weeks following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol). This condition typically manifests with the classic symptoms of parkinsonism (e.g., cogwheel rigidity, stiff gait, tremor); it does not cause involuntary movements of the tongue and face. In addition, this condition typically improves with benztropine therapy.

Tourette syndrome is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary vocal and motor tics. Patients with this condition can develop involuntary movements of the tongue and face. However, Tourette syndrome typically manifests during childhood. This patient's age and history of chronic use of a first-generation antipsychotic indicate another diagnosis.

Serotonin syndrome is a life-threatening condition that most commonly develops due to concurrent use of ≥ 2 serotonergic drugs. It classically manifests with autonomic dysfunction (e.g., diaphoresis, fever), altered mental status (e.g., confusion, agitation, anxiety), and neuromuscular excitability (e,g., hypertonia, myoclonus, tremor), none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, this patient does not take a serotonergic medication.

Huntington disease is a neurologic disorder that can manifest with choreiform movements of the face. However, symptoms of this condition typically develop in the fourth or fifth decade of life. In addition, this patient does not have other typical features of Huntington disease, including hyperreflexia, sensory deficits, and autonomic disturbances. This patient's history of chronic use of a first-generation antipsychotic indicates another diagnosis.

Restless legs syndrome is a neurologic sleep disorder characterized by abnormal, nonpainful sensations in the legs and an irresistible urge to move them, especially during periods of rest. This condition is not associated with involuntary movements of the tongue and face.

question_text:
For each patient treated with an antipsychotic medication, select the most likely diagnosis.
A) Tardive dyskinesia
B) Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
C) Akathisia
D) Acute dystonia
E) Pseudoparkinsonism
F) Tourette syndrome
G) Serotonin syndrome
H) Huntington disease
I) Restless legs syndrome
A 30-year-old man is brought to the physician by his husband because of difficulty walking over the past 7 days. He reports feeling stiffness in the legs and has difficulty standing from a seated position. He has bipolar I disorder treated with lithium carbonate. He has been hospitalized 5 times over the past 8 months for acute manic episodes. During his last hospitalization 10 days ago, fluphenazine therapy was initiated. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/73 mm Hg. Physical examination shows increased resistance to passive movement of the joints in the lower extremities. The patient takes short, quick steps during ambulation and has difficulty maintaining his balance while standing. Gentle tapping between the eyebrows causes the patient to close his eyes.

A) Tardive dyskinesia B) Neuroleptic malignant syndrome C) Akathisia D) Acute dystonia E) Pseudoparkinsonism F) Tourette syndrome G) Serotonin syndrome H) Huntington disease I) Restless legs syndrome A 30-year-old man is brought to the physician by his husband because of difficulty walking over the past 7 days. He reports feeling stiffness in the legs and has difficulty standing from a seated position. He has bipolar I disorder treated with lithium carbonate. He has been hospitalized 5 times over the past 8 months for acute manic episodes. During his last hospitalization 10 days ago, fluphenazine therapy was initiated. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/73 mm Hg. Physical examination shows increased resistance to passive movement of the joints in the lower extremities. The patient takes short, quick steps during ambulation and has difficulty maintaining his balance while standing. Gentle tapping between the eyebrows causes the patient to close his eyes.
hint: Fluphenazine is a first-generation antipsychotic medication that blocks dopamine receptors.
learning_objective: Distinguish pseudoparkinsonism from other causes of involuntary movements.

answers.explanation_why: Tardive dyskinesia is a movement disorder that can manifest within months to years following the administration of dopamine-blocking agents (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as fluphenazine). It most commonly causes involuntary movements of the tongue and mouth (e.g., lip-smacking, repetitive chewing); it does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening condition that can develop within the first 2 weeks following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as fluphenazine). This condition causes muscular rigidity, but it does not cause a shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex. In addition, this patient lacks other typical characteristics of NMS, including hyperthermia, autonomic instability, and altered mental status.

Akathisia is a movement disorder that can manifest within 1–8 weeks following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as fluphenazine). This condition is characterized by motor restlessness (i.e., a compelling urge to move), which can manifest with an inability to sit or stand still; it does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex.

Acute dystonia is an adverse effect of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as fluphenazine) that can manifest within hours to days after initiation of therapy. This condition typically causes painful, lasting muscle spasms that most commonly affect the head, neck, and tongue, which this patient does not have. Acute dystonia does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex.

Pseudoparkinsonism is a drug-induced movement disorder that can develop days to weeks after the initiation of dopamine-blocking agents (e.g., first-generation antipsychotics). This condition manifests with symptoms of parkinsonism, such as limb rigidity, shuffling gait, bradykinesia, postural instability, and an unhabituated glabellar reflex, all of which are seen in this patient. Lithium therapy is also associated with pseudoparkinsonism; the combination of lithium and fluphenazine therapy increased this patient's risk of developing this condition. Other medications associated with pseudoparkinsonism include metoclopramide and valproate.

images.title: Timeline of extrapyramidal symptoms induced by antipsychotics

answers.explanation_why: Tourette syndrome is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary vocal and motor tics. It does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex. Moreover, Tourette syndrome typically manifests during childhood.

Serotonin syndrome is a life-threatening condition that most commonly develops due to concurrent use of ≥ 2 serotonergic drugs. It classically manifests with autonomic dysfunction (e.g., diaphoresis, fever), altered mental status (e.g., confusion, agitation, anxiety), and neuromuscular excitability (e,g., hypertonia, myoclonus, tremor), none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, this patient does not take a serotonergic medication.

Huntington disease is a neurologic disorder that typically manifests with choreiform movements, cognitive decline, behavioral changes, hyperreflexia, sensory deficits, and autonomic disturbances in the fourth or fifth decade of life. This patient does not show these features. Moreover, Huntington disease does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex.

Restless legs syndrome is a neurologic sleep disorder characterized by abnormal, nonpainful sensations in the legs and an irresistible urge to move them, especially during periods of rest. This condition does not manifest with limb rigidity, shuffling gait, postural instability, or an unhabituated glabellar reflex.

question_text: Four-month-old twins are brought to the physician for a well-child examination. They were born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy and have been healthy since. The birth weight of the first infant was 2606 g (6 lb 3 oz); his current weight is 6600 g (14 lb 9 oz) and he is at the 30^th percentile. The birth weight of the second infant was 2580 g (5 lb 11 oz); her current weight is 6500 g (14 lb 5 oz) and she is at the 25^th percentile. Both of the twins can raise their head and chest in the prone position, reach for objects, localize sounds, and smile at sounds and sights. Two weeks ago, the female twin started propping herself up on her hands when prone. The mother expresses concern because the other twin is still unable to do so. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: Four-month-old twins are brought to the physician for a well-child examination. They were born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy and have been healthy since. The birth weight of the first infant was 2606 g (6 lb 3 oz); his current weight is 6600 g (14 lb 9 oz) and he is at the 30th percentile. The birth weight of the second infant was 2580 g (5 lb 11 oz); her current weight is 6500 g (14 lb 5 oz) and she is at the 25th percentile. Both of the twins can raise their head and chest in the prone position, reach for objects, localize sounds, and smile at sounds and sights. Two weeks ago, the female twin started propping herself up on her hands when prone. The mother expresses concern because the other twin is still unable to do so. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: Twins, like all other children, develop at different speeds, and each twin should be evaluated separately for any delays in obtaining milestones.
learning_objective: Recognize that developmental milestones can vary between twins and reassure accordingly.

answers.content: "There is no reason for concern, but I will order blood tests to rule out a genetic disorder."
answers.explanation_why: Further evaluation including reviewing the newborn screening test and assessing for a genetic disorder would be warranted if the twin who cannot yet prop himself up failed to obtain the milestone by the time of his next well-child examination. At this time, there is no reason to pursue further testing.

answers.content: "I will refer you to a developmental pediatrician for further assessment."
answers.explanation_why: Further evaluation including a referral to a developmental pediatrician would be warranted if the twin who cannot yet prop himself up failed to obtain the milestone by the time of his next well-child examination. At this time, there is no reason for a referral.

answers.content: "We will set up examinations at shorter intervals until both children have achieved the same milestones."
answers.explanation_why: The twin who is unable to prop himself up will need to be reassessed at his next well-child examination, but there is no need to set up examinations at shorter intervals. Frequent examinations are only required for infants with certain risk factors (e.g., perinatal complications, genetic disorders, history of living in impoverished conditions, and/or domestic violence in the family), which are not present here.

answers.content: "I will order a detailed neurological assessment to further investigate your child's developmental delay."
answers.explanation_why: The twin who is unable to prop himself up would need a detailed neurological assessment only if he has red flags (e.g., hypertonia/hypotonia, dysmorphism, failure to thrive, positive newborn screening). Since he does not have any such red flags a detailed neurological assessment is not indicated at this time; he only needs to be reassessed at his next well-child examination. If he has failed to obtain the milestone by then, a detailed neurological examination will be performed.

answers.content: "There is no need to worry because differences between twins reaching milestones are normal."
answers.explanation_why: Developmental milestones are based on the mean age at which children can perform a particular task. Individual differences in the age at which some developmental milestones are achieved are normal. The mean age at which infants attain the ability to prop themselves up with their hands while prone is 6 months. Therefore, the mother of these 4-month-old twins should be reassured, while the children should be reevaluated during the next well-child visit at 6 months of age. A developmental delay should be suspected if a particular milestone does not occur by the expected age.

question_text: A gynecologist is approached by a close personal friend after a church service that they attended together. “You know Marc and I are going on vacation next week. I totally did not see this coming, but I am going to run out of my birth control pill. I am afraid I won't be able to get my prescription filled before we leave because the next few days will be very busy. I know this is awkward, but could you please write me a prescription just to cover the time until I am back from vacation?”. The physician has known the friend for many years and she knows that she has no personal history of serious illness. The friend is an attorney who has a hectic schedule, which the physician sympathizes with. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A gynecologist is approached by a close personal friend after a church service that they attended together. “You know Marc and I are going on vacation next week. I totally did not see this coming, but I am going to run out of my birth control pill. I am afraid I won't be able to get my prescription filled before we leave because the next few days will be very busy. I know this is awkward, but could you please write me a prescription just to cover the time until I am back from vacation?”. The physician has known the friend for many years and she knows that she has no personal history of serious illness. The friend is an attorney who has a hectic schedule, which the physician sympathizes with. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: It is important that a physician always weigh the urgency of the care they are being asked to provide with objectivity towards the patient and the situation.
learning_objective: Recognize when it is inappropriate to prescribe medication to friends or family.

answers.content: Suggest that friend use condoms for contraception during their vacation
answers.explanation_why: Condoms are an alternative form of contraception for this patient. However, physicians should generally avoid making professional consultations to close friends and family because they can be subject to conflict between emotional relationships and objectivity.

answers.content: Inform the friend that it is never appropriate for a physician to be involved in the treatment of a friend or family member
answers.explanation_why: Physicians should generally refrain from the treatment of family and friends because professional objectivity can be clouded by emotion. However, this principle does not apply to all situations, such as when emergency treatment is indicated.

answers.content: Prescribe oral contraceptives if the friend agrees to undergo a proper physical examination
answers.explanation_why: Whenever possible, a thorough physical examination should be performed before prescribing any medication or initiating any treatment. However, even after a thorough physical examination, it would not be appropriate for a physician to prescribe an elective medication to a friend in this case.

answers.content: Prescribe oral contraceptives after ruling out that the friend has any contraindications, but emphasize that this is an exception
answers.explanation_why: Contraindications have to be ruled out before prescribing any medications. However, even after ruling out contraindications, it would not be appropriate for this physician to prescribe elective medication to a friend in this case.

answers.content: Explain that it is not appropriate to prescribe medication to a friend unless in an emergency
answers.explanation_why: According to the American Medical Association (AMA) Code of Medical Ethics, self-treatment, treatment of immediate family, and treatment of close friends should only occur in emergency situations. An emotional relationship with a patient can interfere with a physician's objective judgment. Their relationship may cause the physician or patient to be uncomfortable obtaining a full history and physical exam (e.g., sexual history and genitourinary exam). It is not appropriate for the physician to provide treatment to their friend in this non-emergency situation. In this case, the physician should politely decline while explaining their concerns and help the friend to find a more appropriate physician.

question_text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Three months ago, she was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision that resulted in burn injuries in the face and neck region requiring skin transplantation. She appears teary and does not make eye contact. Physical examination shows hypertrophic pink burn scars on the left side of the chin and cheek and well-healed wounds over the transplantation site on the left side of her neck. The patient says “I can't go out, I can't meet friends, and I can't even imagine trying to date since the accident.” Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response to the patient?
content_preview: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Three months ago, she was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision that resulted in burn injuries in the face and neck region requiring skin transplantation. She appears teary and does not make eye contact. Physical examination shows hypertrophic pink burn scars on the left side of the chin and cheek and well-healed wounds over the transplantation site on the left side of her neck. The patient says “I can't go out, I can't meet friends, and I can't even imagine trying to date since the accident.” Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response to the patient?
hint: Disfiguring injuries increase the risk of developing psychological disorders.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate initial response to address a patient's emotional distress.

answers.content: "Have you had any thoughts about ending your life?"
answers.explanation_why: Assessment of suicidal ideation is an important step in the management of patients with psychiatric disorders. This patient with disfiguring injuries is at risk for developing a major depressive disorder, which is associated with suicidal thoughts. However, her reaction to her condition should be evaluated prior to assessing for suicidal ideation.

answers.content: “Would you like to know more about options for additional cosmetic surgery that we can offer?“
answers.explanation_why: Plastic procedures can be appropriate adjuvant steps in the management of patients with disfiguring injuries. However, surgery does not address the psychosocial impact of the injury on this patient's life and it is inappropriate to assume she wishes to pursue surgery at this time. Her reaction to her condition should be assessed first in order to evaluate which treatments may be helpful.

answers.content: "Can you tell me why you feel this way?"
answers.explanation_why: This patient with burn scars presents with mental distress and is at an increased risk of developing psychological disorders (e.g., depression, posttraumatic stress disorder, social phobia). In addition to medical treatment of the wounds, psychosocial care should be provided. The most appropriate initial response is to ask an open-ended question to explore the patient's reaction and adjustment to her condition. The physician should not offer false reassurance. After listening to the patient's response, further discussion is needed to identify treatment needs and options.

answers.content: “Would you like to speak to a specialist in postinjury social phobia who might be able to help you?”
answers.explanation_why: A referral to a specialist in postinjury social phobia can be an appropriate adjuvant step in the management of patients with disfiguring injuries. However, this step would only be indicated after the diagnosis of social phobia. This patient's reaction to her condition must be explored first in order to evaluate which treatments may be helpful.

answers.content: "I think you still look very beautiful. Why does this affect you that much?"
answers.explanation_why: Hope is an important factor for psychosocial adjustment in patients with disfiguring injuries. Although reassurance by a physician can help the patient establish such hope, a personal remark on the appearance of a patient transgresses the physician-patient boundary. This patient's reaction to her illness should be evaluated first.

answers.content: "Do you have family or friends that support you and you can talk to about your feelings?"
answers.explanation_why: Social support is an important factor for the psychosocial adjustment of patients with disfiguring injuries and a discussion on the patient's social support system should take place. However, it is the physician's responsibility to first evaluate the patient's reaction to her condition, especially because patients with disfiguring injuries are at increased risk of psychological disorders. The physician cannot pass on the task of assessing her feelings to her social support system.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of bilateral breast pain for the past 4 months. The symptom started after she began taking oral contraceptives prescribed by the physician. She appears upset and says, “This is ridiculous! Ever since you prescribed me these pills, my breasts hurt almost every day and it is taking a toll on my relationship; my boyfriend can't even get near me.” She has no family history of breast cancer. Breast examination shows mild bilateral diffuse tenderness and no masses. There is no redness, swelling, or warmth of the breasts. The physician apologizes for her pain and explains the risks and benefits of alternative methods of contraception. When the physician suggests a copper intrauterine device, the patient seems unsure. The patient says she does not want to use nonhormonal alternatives because they are too unsafe. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of bilateral breast pain for the past 4 months. The symptom started after she began taking oral contraceptives prescribed by the physician. She appears upset and says, “This is ridiculous! Ever since you prescribed me these pills, my breasts hurt almost every day and it is taking a toll on my relationship; my boyfriend can't even get near me.” She has no family history of breast cancer. Breast examination shows mild bilateral diffuse tenderness and no masses. There is no redness, swelling, or warmth of the breasts. The physician apologizes for her pain and explains the risks and benefits of alternative methods of contraception. When the physician suggests a copper intrauterine device, the patient seems unsure. The patient says she does not want to use nonhormonal alternatives because they are too unsafe. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: When counseling on contraception, it is important to explore the patient's preferences and concerns about the different available methods.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of shared decision-making in patient-physician communication, and choose the most appropriate response to assess patient understanding.

answers.content: "Your symptoms are unlikely to be related to the oral contraceptive pill."
answers.explanation_why: This statement is incorrect. Breast pain is a common side effect of oral contraceptive pills. Moreover, the patient's opinion should be acknowledged.

answers.content: "Most of my patients in situations like yours have been very happy using this contraceptive method."
answers.explanation_why: Disclosure of other patients' experiences with a specific medication can influence a patient's decision. In this case, the patient's uncertainties about nonhormonal contraceptives were not acknowledged by the physician. Instead of mentioning other patients' experiences, the physician should provide neutral information to empower the patient in the shared decision-making process.

answers.content: "Can you explain to me your understanding of how a copper intrauterine device works?"
answers.explanation_why: Enabling a shared decision-making process by ensuring that a patient understands a treatment or procedure is a key principle in patient-physician communication. A useful way to uncover possible misunderstandings is by asking the patient for his or her own perspective on a medication or procedure. Other features of shared decision-making include ensuring the patient knows his or her options, providing relevant facts, and encouraging the patient to discuss his or her thoughts about the options.

answers.content: "I really recommend trying a nonhormonal contraceptive. They are also very safe if used correctly."
answers.explanation_why: Breast pain is a common side effect of hormonal contraceptives and would likely resolve if the patient switched to a nonhormonal contraceptive. However, this patient explicitly stated that she is worried about the safety of nonhormonal contraceptives. The patient's preferences should not be dismissed; more information should be provided about the safety of nonhormonal contraceptives.

answers.content: "You seem unsure about the options presented. Would you like me to give you my personal opinion to help you with this decision?"
answers.explanation_why: Reflecting the patient's feelings to demonstrate listening and understanding is a good method of strengthening the patient-physician relationship. However, in a shared decision-making process, the physician should be as objective as possible and provide neutral information about the different options rather than offer personal opinions.

question_text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the family physician for a routine health maintenance examination. The patient and her family, including her mother and father, have all been in the physician's care for the past 20 years, and the patient regularly accompanies her parents to their appointments. During the examination, the patient mentions that she is concerned that her 70-year-old father has recently bought a parcel of land and now wants to build a new home on it. Her father worked as a contractor for 30 years before going into retirement and plans to build the house himself with only minor help from other contractors. The patient explains that she is worried her father will injure himself while working on the house and “dig himself into a financial hole.” She asks the physician whether he could speak to her father about his plans and explain to him that these would be too much of a physical and financial risk for a person of his age. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician at this time?
content_preview: A 30-year-old woman comes to the family physician for a routine health maintenance examination. The patient and her family, including her mother and father, have all been in the physician's care for the past 20 years, and the patient regularly accompanies her parents to their appointments. During the examination, the patient mentions that she is concerned that her 70-year-old father has recently bought a parcel of land and now wants to build a new home on it. Her father worked as a contractor for 30 years before going into retirement and plans to build the house himself with only minor help from other contractors. The patient explains that she is worried her father will injure himself while working on the house and “dig himself into a financial hole.” She asks the physician whether he could speak to her father about his plans and explain to him that these would be too much of a physical and financial risk for a person of his age. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician at this time?
hint: This physician has an obligation of confidentiality, beneficence, and autonomy to both of his patients; fulfilling this relative's request could violate the autonomy principle and compromise a physician-patient relationship.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate response to respect patient autonomy and confidentiality in family matters.

answers.content: "I encourage you to speak to your father directly about your concerns. If you're unable to resolve the situation on your own, I can refer you to a family therapist."
answers.explanation_why:
Clinicians who provide care for multiple members of the same family are sometimes confronted with family conflicts. Physicians should not take sides since it compromises at least one clinician-patient relationship. The clinician should encourage conflict resolution because impaired family relationships can negatively impact health outcomes. If conflicts between family members cannot be resolved, the clinician can suggest referral to a family therapist.

Clinicians may need to intervene in family conflicts involving suspected abuse.

answers.content: "I believe this constitutes a legal dispute. As such, I think you should contact a lawyer."
answers.explanation_why: The patient's concern for her father's physical and financial wellbeing does not constitute a legal dispute, so this response would not be appropriate.

answers.content: "I must admit that I agree with your concerns. I will bring this up when I have the next appointment with your father."
answers.explanation_why: The physician cannot agree with the patient's concerns because by doing so the physician takes sides in a family conflict; the physician must remain neutral. The physician also cannot mention the daughter's concerns in the next appointment with the father, because doing so would breach the obligation of confidentiality to the daughter.

answers.content: "I understand you are concerned, but it is your father's right to make such decisions. You should try to support him in his decision."
answers.explanation_why: This would not be an appropriate response to the patient's request, because the physician is giving their personal opinion about this family conflict and indirectly blaming this patient for not supporting her father. The physician should attempt to stay neutral and suggest other ways to deal with this family issue.

answers.content: "I understand you are concerned, but I should not be involved in such family matters, especially if they are not directly related to your father's medical care."
answers.explanation_why: This response is partially correct because the physician's involvement in the family conflict is not directly related to the patient's medical care. However, this is not the most appropriate response because, besides being neutral, the physician should further advise the patient to seek conflict resolution.

question_text: A 52-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of bright red anal bleeding. Her current medications include warfarin and metoprolol. One month ago, her primary care physician increased the dose of warfarin because of subtherapeutic coagulation studies. A repeat coagulation study was ordered for the following week. Today, the physician realizes that the test results were sent back to the office 18 days ago and show a prothrombin time of 43 seconds (INR = 4.0). Which of the following actions is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of bright red anal bleeding. Her current medications include warfarin and metoprolol. One month ago, her primary care physician increased the dose of warfarin because of subtherapeutic coagulation studies. A repeat coagulation study was ordered for the following week. Today, the physician realizes that the test results were sent back to the office 18 days ago and show a prothrombin time of 43 seconds (INR = 4.0). Which of the following actions is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
hint: The delay in the follow-up of the patient's test results lead to a delay in the dose-adjustment of warfarin and, subsequently, a preventable adverse drug event. This medical error can be prevented by standardization, a principle of human factors engineering.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of standardization to prevent delays in test result follow-up.

answers.content: Instruct the office front staff to label all abnormal test results as "urgent."
answers.explanation_why: Critical test results, which require an immediate review by a physician (e.g., high PT/INR, derangements in potassium levels), can be labeled as “urgent” in order to bring these results to the attention of the caregiver sooner and thereby help prevent a delay in follow-up. However, this measure can only be implemented successfully by trained personnel (e.g., physicians, laboratory technicians, nurses); office front staff are not trained to identify critical test results; if they are instructed to label all abnormal test results as “urgent,” alert fatigue can occur and cause the physician to ignore the “urgent” label.

answers.content: Provide the patient with a visual medication schedule for warfarin use.
answers.explanation_why: The use of a visual medication schedule (VMS) for patients receiving warfarin has been shown to decrease the time needed to reach an optimal PT/INR level. However, a VMS is used to prevent communication errors (e.g., patient-physician discordance) and improve patient compliance rather than to prevent an error caused by a delay in follow-up.

answers.content: Maintain a record of therapeutic drug monitoring tests that need reviewing.
answers.explanation_why:
Standardization of protocols for the follow-up of test results (e.g., maintaining a record of therapeutic drug monitoring tests that need to be reviewed, or a record of tests with pending results) can help prevent medical errors that occur as a result of a delay in follow-up by the physician. Protocols help ensure a consistent level of quality and increase efficiency (e.g., reduce the variation in follow-up time and increase the likelihood of the physician reviewing critical test results as soon as they arrive). By using a standardized protocol, the physician would have been notified that the patient's INR was too high earlier, could have adjusted the warfarin dose in time, and thereby have prevented the anal bleeding.

Further examples of standardization include the introduction of checklists and guidelines as well as standardized equipment and terminology.

answers.content: Ask the patient to sign up for online access to her diagnostic test results.
answers.explanation_why: The involvement of the patient in safety efforts can act as a check to prevent medical errors (multilayered safety system of a swiss cheese model); an online portal that provides patients access to their test results can reduce the risk of a delay in follow-up because patients are likely to contact their physician in the case of an abnormal result. However, several patient-related factors (e.g., lack of internet access, low literacy level, low motivation, inability to interpret test results), and design-related factors (e.g., poor ease-of-use) can limit the usefulness of these portals. Moreover, this step does not address the physician's responsibility to follow up on the patient's results in a timely manner and lays this responsibility squarely on the patient.

answers.content: Administer an initial bridging therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin.
answers.explanation_why: Initial bridging therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin is used to prevent thromboembolic events associated with the initiation of warfarin (e.g., warfarin-induced skin necrosis) rather than to prevent bleeding.

question_text: An 84-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because of hair loss over the past 2 months. The patient has a history of hypertension, major depressive disorder, allergic rhinitis, osteoarthritis, and diverticular disease. She lived with her daughter, son-in-law, and their 3 children until recently, when her daughter got divorced and had to move into an apartment. The patient was moved to an assisted living facility nearby, and her daughter has not been able to visit as often as planned. Her medications include diltiazem, venlafaxine, loratadine, acetaminophen, and fiber supplements. She appears withdrawn. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the head is shown. There is no scarring of the skin. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hair loss?
content_preview: An 84-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because of hair loss over the past 2 months. The patient has a history of hypertension, major depressive disorder, allergic rhinitis, osteoarthritis, and diverticular disease. She lived with her daughter, son-in-law, and their 3 children until recently, when her daughter got divorced and had to move into an apartment. The patient was moved to an assisted living facility nearby, and her daughter has not been able to visit as often as planned. Her medications include diltiazem, venlafaxine, loratadine, acetaminophen, and fiber supplements. She appears withdrawn. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the head is shown. There is no scarring of the skin. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hair loss?
hint: This patient experienced significant stressors when she was moved away from her family to an assisted living facility after her daughter's divorce.
learning_objective: Recognize compulsive hair pulling (trichotillomania).

answers.content: Modified regulation of the growth cycle of hair follicles
answers.explanation_why: Telogen effluvium is caused by a modification in the regulation of the growth cycle of the hair follicle, leading to diffuse, nonscarring hair loss. Although psychological stress can trigger telogen effluvium, this condition does not manifest with patches of hair of varying lengths. Additionally, hair density in telogen effluvium typically decreases by < 50%; this patient has normal hair density.

images.title: Telogen effluvium
images.description: Head of a patient 5 months after bariatric surgeryThe frontal (a) and the left side (b) of the scalp show a diffuse, nonscarring loss of hair. This appearance is caused by premature shedding of hair follicles in telogen phase (resting phase).Telogen effluvium can be caused, for example, by stress such as a surgery or severe febrile illness.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's patches of hair of varying lengths that occurred following stressful events suggest trichotillomania. Patients with trichotillomania often have an underlying psychiatric disorder, such as major depressive disorder. Trichotillomania is more common in women than men and manifests most commonly in teenagers, although it can occur at any age, particularly in the setting of multiple stressors. Hair-pulling can occur at the scalp, as seen in this patient, as well as eyebrows and eyelashes. The first-line treatment for trichotillomania is cognitive behavioral therapy, specifically habit reversal training (HRT). SSRIs may be used if there is coexisting OCD, anxiety, or depression, but the evidence for SSRIs in trichotillomania alone is limited.

Hair loss can occur as a side effect of medication (e.g., isotretinoin, lithium, colchicine). However, none of the medications that this patient is taking are commonly associated with hair loss. Moreover, this patient has new hair growth and normal hair density, neither of which is consistent with medication-induced hair loss.

Immune-mediated inflammation of hair follicles is the underlying cause of alopecia areata, which can cause stress-related hair loss without scarring. Although alopecia areata most commonly affects the scalp, irregular patches of hair of varying lengths would not be expected. Instead, affected individuals typically present with well-demarcated, smooth, rounded patches of hair loss and exclamation-point hairs as well as nail involvement. Moreover, alopecia areata is mainly seen in people < 30 years old; this patient is 84 years old.

Dermatophyte infections of the scalp (e.g., tinea capitis) can cause hair loss. Tinea capitis typically does not manifest with hair of varying lengths, nor is it associated with stress. In addition, typical clinical features of tinea capitis, including round, pruritic scaly plaques with broken hair shafts and postauricular lymphadenopathy, are not present in this patient. Moreover, tinea capitis is seen primarily in children; this patient is 84 years old.

answers.content: Increased androgen sensitivity of hair follicles
answers.explanation_why: Increased androgen sensitivity of hair follicles causes androgenetic alopecia, which can manifest as nonscarring balding of the crown and frontal scalp in women. However, androgenic alopecia does not typically manifest with patches of hair of different lengths, as seen in this patient, nor is it associated with stress. Rather, the hair loss in androgenetic alopecia is progressive; diffuse hair thinning of the entire scalp would be expected. Additionally, this patient does not have hirsutism or acne, which are characteristic signs of androgen excess.

images.title: Trichotillomania
images.description: There are patches of hair of varying length. The hair density is normal (including new hair growth).

question_text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of unexplained weight loss over the past 8 months. During the examination, he tells the physician that he has been having marital issues with his wife. He filed for bankruptcy 2 months ago for a business he had owned with his brother until his brother died of skin cancer a year ago. He has tried to hide his financial issues from his wife and explains that he is feeling increasingly desperate and no longer “sees the light at the end of the tunnel.” He worries about finances and what would happen if he developed cancer like his brother, and then cannot fall asleep. In the morning, he feels tired and finds it hard to start the day. The patient says the symptoms began a few months after his brother's death and then, “Everything started to fall apart. I can't concentrate, my wife will probably leave me soon, and now I have lost the business.” Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of unexplained weight loss over the past 8 months. During the examination, he tells the physician that he has been having marital issues with his wife. He filed for bankruptcy 2 months ago for a business he had owned with his brother until his brother died of skin cancer a year ago. He has tried to hide his financial issues from his wife and explains that he is feeling increasingly desperate and no longer “sees the light at the end of the tunnel.” He worries about finances and what would happen if he developed cancer like his brother, and then cannot fall asleep. In the morning, he feels tired and finds it hard to start the day. The patient says the symptoms began a few months after his brother's death and then, “Everything started to fall apart. I can't concentrate, my wife will probably leave me soon, and now I have lost the business.” Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician?
hint: This patient, who presents with a depressed mood, sleep disturbance, fatigue, diminished concentration, and weight loss over a period > 2 weeks, is experiencing a major depressive episode.
learning_objective: Recognize symptoms of a major depressive episode and assess for suicidal ideation.

answers.content: "I cannot imagine how hard this must be for you. You say you no longer see the light at the end of the tunnel. Are you having thoughts of suicide?"
answers.explanation_why: Through this reaction, the physician shows empathy and specifically asks about suicidal ideation. Assessing a patient's suicide risk is the most important diagnostic step for any depressed individual. If the patient confirms that he is having suicidal ideation, the physician should also ask the patient if he has thought of a means of suicide (suicidal plan), assess the degree to which he intends to put the plan into action (suicidal intent), and evaluate whether additional risk factors for suicide completion are present (e.g., possession of a firearm, personal and family history of prior suicide attempts). If the patient is suicidal, they should be admitted to the hospital. Treatment of a major depressive episode often requires a combination of antidepressants, psychotherapy, and lifestyle changes.

answers.content: "Considering what you have been going through, it is absolutely normal to feel that way. You will see that things will become easier for you over time!"
answers.explanation_why: Through this reaction, the physician minimizes the patient's symptoms. Although it could be normal for the patient to occasionally have some of his symptoms (e.g., depressed mood, decreased sleep, decreased concentration) as a part of grief, it is not normal to have them on a persistent basis or have unexplained weight loss over 8 months. Moreover, by saying, “You will see that things will become easier for you over time!" the physician is making promises that cannot be guaranteed.

answers.content: "It sounds like you are depressed, but before we begin treatment for depression, I would like to evaluate you for any underlying conditions that may be causing your mood changes."
answers.explanation_why: Depression can be caused by organic conditions (e.g., hypothyroidism, CNS neoplasm, Parkinson disease), and it is necessary to evaluate patients with features of depression for organic disease. However, since depression can be life-threatening, there is something more pressing that the physician should first address with this patient.

answers.content: "This is obviously a very difficult time for you and it would be normal to turn to certain substances when you are feeling this way. Would you be willing to provide a urine sample for testing?"
answers.explanation_why: Depression can be caused by a substance use disorder, and it is necessary to evaluate any patient with features of depression for a substance use disorder. However, it would be inappropriate to perform a urine toxicology screen before first directly asking the patient about substance use and examining the patient for signs of a substance use disorder.

answers.content: "Losing your brother must have been extremely hard for you. Would you be willing to speak with a grief counselor?"
answers.explanation_why: A referral to a grief counselor is appropriate for the management of grief, which is caused by the death of a loved one and can present with symptoms such as a depressed mood, disturbed sleep, and decreased concentration, as seen here. However, the symptoms of grief tend to occur in waves (grief pangs), decrease over time, and are not associated with functional impairment or feelings of desperation. This patient's presentation is consistent with a major depressive episode and cannot be treated by grief counseling alone. Moreover, even in patients with grief, it is important to first ask a specific question in order to differentiate normal from pathological grief.

answers.content: "After the death of your brother, it is even more important to stay close to your family. What do you think about starting to attend family therapy with your wife?"
answers.explanation_why: The patient said that he has been having marital issues with his wife, so seeing a family therapist with his wife could be beneficial. However, since depression can be life-threatening, there is something more pressing that the physician should first address with this patient.

question_text:
A group of investigators is planning a phase III clinical trial to assess whether the histone deacetylase 3 inhibitor BG45 should be used in the treatment of multiple myeloma (MM). Which of the following sets of characteristics best describes this clinical trial phase?

Study purpose
Study population

A
Evaluate the safety of BG45
Small number of healthy volunteers

B
Evaluate the efficacy and safety of BG45 against the standard of care
Large number of patients with MM

C
Evaluate the efficacy and safety of BG45
Small number of patients with MM

D
Evaluate the safety of BG45
Large number of patients with MM

E
Evaluate the efficacy and safety of BG45
Small number of mice with MM

F
Evaluate the efficacy and safety of BG45 against the standard of care
Small number of patients with MM
content_preview: A group of investigators is planning a phase III clinical trial to assess whether the histone deacetylase 3 inhibitor BG45 should be used in the treatment of multiple myeloma (MM). Which of the following sets of characteristics best describes this clinical trial phase? Study purpose Study population A Evaluate the safety of BG45 Small number of healthy volunteers B Evaluate the efficacy and safety of BG45 against the standard of care Large number of patients with MM C Evaluate the efficacy and safety of BG45 Small number of patients with MM D Evaluate the safety of BG45 Large number of patients with MM E Evaluate the efficacy and safety of BG45 Small number of mice with MM F Evaluate the efficacy and safety of BG45 against the standard of care Small number of patients with MM
hint: Phase III clinical trials are randomized controlled trials, in which enrolled patients are randomly allocated to either a treatment or control group.
learning_objective: Recall the purpose and design of phase 3 clinical trials.

answers.explanation_why: This set of characteristics describes a phase I clinical trial, the main objective of which is to assess the safety and toxicity of a new treatment. Phase I trials include the assessment of pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. This phase involves a small number of healthy volunteers or patients with the disease that the drug is intended to treat. Phase I clinical trials are only started if cell and animal studies suggest that the new treatment is likely to be effective and safe in humans.

This set of characteristics describes a phase III clinical trial in which a new treatment is compared with the current standard of care or placebo in terms of safety and efficacy. This phase involves a large number of patients, who are randomly divided into two groups: One group is treated with the current standard of care or placebo and the other is given the new treatment. Outcomes are then analyzed. If the new treatment proves to be more effective and/or safer than the current standard treatment, a new drug application is submitted to regulatory agencies (the Food and Drug Administration in the United States) for approval.

This set of characteristics describes a phase II clinical trial, the main objective of which is to assess the efficacy of a drug. In this phase, a small number of patients are treated with the dose found to be the safest in phase I clinical trials.

This set of characteristics describes a phase IV clinical trial. In this phase, the main objective is to evaluate safety over time, assessing for long-term and rare adverse effects in a large number of patients. Treatments that are currently in phase IV clinical trials have already received approval from regulatory agencies (the Food and Drug Administration in the United States) and are already being used in the clinical setting. Phase IV trials are used for postmarketing surveillance.

This set of characteristics describes a preclinical trial in which in vitro experiments and animal models are used. The main objective of preclinical trials is to assess whether the new treatment is likely to be effective and safe in humans.

This set of characteristics does not describe any phase of a clinical trial. Although there is a phase of clinical trials that aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a drug against the standard of care, this type of clinical trial is carried out with a large number of patients.

question_text: A group of investigators conducts an unblinded, randomized controlled trial to investigate the effect of single-agent pomalidomide on the survival of patients with smoldering multiple myeloma (SMM). Three-hundred eligible patients with SMM are randomized to receive 6 cycles of either pomalidomide or a placebo. At the 24-month follow-up, the investigators find that a significant number of patients were not adherent with the treatment assigned or lost to follow-up. Nonetheless, results for the patients who completed the protocol showed that pomalidomide improves progression-free survival. The investigators are worried about potential biases resulting from the significant loss to follow-up and nonadherence in the treatment group. Which of the following is the most appropriate technique to minimize selection bias and provide the most valid estimate of the real effect of pomalidomide on patients with SMM?
content_preview: A group of investigators conducts an unblinded, randomized controlled trial to investigate the effect of single-agent pomalidomide on the survival of patients with smoldering multiple myeloma (SMM). Three-hundred eligible patients with SMM are randomized to receive 6 cycles of either pomalidomide or a placebo. At the 24-month follow-up, the investigators find that a significant number of patients were not adherent with the treatment assigned or lost to follow-up. Nonetheless, results for the patients who completed the protocol showed that pomalidomide improves progression-free survival. The investigators are worried about potential biases resulting from the significant loss to follow-up and nonadherence in the treatment group. Which of the following is the most appropriate technique to minimize selection bias and provide the most valid estimate of the real effect of pomalidomide on patients with SMM?
hint: This technique can be used to preserve the benefits of randomization and provide a more conservative estimate of the effect of pomalidomide in patients with SMM.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate statistical method to minimize selection bias in randomized controlled trials with nonadherence and loss to follow-up.

answers.explanation_why: A subgroup analysis (or stratified data analysis) is a statistical method that can be used when a third variable seems to either influence a study outcome (effect modifier) or correlate with the exposure and the outcome (confounder). Study groups are divided into subgroups according to the third variable and measures of association can be calculated for each subgroup. A subgroup analysis adjusts for an effect modifier or a confounder. In the described study, this method can improve the estimate of the real effect of pomalidomide on patients with SMM. However, this technique does not minimize selection bias because the original randomization is lost with this method.

A noninferiority trial is a type of clinical trial that aims to show that the efficacy of a tested treatment is not substantially smaller than the efficacy of the established control treatment. Noninferiority trials are most commonly used when placebo control would be unethical. The described study is an unblinded, randomized controlled trial with a treatment group and a placebo group. By definition, noninferiority trials do not compare treatment to placebo, but rather to control treatment. Furthermore, noninferiority is a study design and not a method of statistical analysis, so it cannot be applied in hindsight. Noninferiority trials are also susceptible to the same biases as superiority trials.

An intention-to-treat analysis is a statistical method in which the data of every patient enrolled in a study is used for data analysis (including data from drop-out patients), and in which each patient is analyzed as part of the treatment group that they were randomly assigned to at the beginning of the study (regardless of the treatment they eventually receive). This analysis includes data from all patients and preserves the original randomization, giving a more accurate estimate of the efficacy of the tested treatment and minimizing selection bias when compared to data analysis that excludes drop-out patients. In the described study, the large drop-out rate as a result of nonadherence and loss to follow-up may have created selection bias and the shown improvement of progression-free survival under pomalidomide may be falsely skewed in favor of the treatment. An intention-to-treat analysis is an appropriate technique to address this bias.

The converse of intention-to-treat analysis is per-protocol analysis.

A per-protocol analysis is a statistical method in which the study groups are compared using data only from the patients who finished the treatment that they were originally assigned. This analysis is used to evaluate the treatment effect under optimal conditions. Using a per-protocol analysis in the described study improves the estimate of the real effect of pomalidomide on patients with SMM. However, this method tends to overestimate the effects of the tested treatment because it does not take into account when patients drop out of the study. Furthermore, this technique does not minimize selection bias because the original randomization is lost with this method.

A crossover trial is a type of clinical study in which each patient serves as their own control. Crossover studies improve the estimates of the real effect of a treatment by reducing confounding bias. However, the described study is an unblinded, randomized controlled trial with a defined treatment group and a placebo group. The patients do not switch from the treatment group to the control group or vice versa during the study. Crossover is a study design and not a method of statistical analysis and cannot be applied in hindsight.

question_text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a follow-up evaluation of a spinal lesion identified during surveillance imaging. One year ago, he had tonsillar squamous cell carcinoma treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He undergoes a CT-guided needle biopsy of the spinal lesion and is awaiting the pathology result. A medical student, who is part of the team involved in the patient's care, sees the patient in the hospital cafeteria. The student has just reviewed the patient's spinal biopsy result, which is consistent with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of oropharyngeal origin. The patient approaches the student in the cafeteria and asks if the biopsy result has come back. Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a follow-up evaluation of a spinal lesion identified during surveillance imaging. One year ago, he had tonsillar squamous cell carcinoma treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He undergoes a CT-guided needle biopsy of the spinal lesion and is awaiting the pathology result. A medical student, who is part of the team involved in the patient's care, sees the patient in the hospital cafeteria. The student has just reviewed the patient's spinal biopsy result, which is consistent with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of oropharyngeal origin. The patient approaches the student in the cafeteria and asks if the biopsy result has come back. Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
hint: The student should act in the best interest of the patient while also being honest with him.
learning_objective: Recognize the appropriate protocol for disclosing patient information as a medical student.

answers.content: "I believe the biopsy showed cancer, but I have to review the result with the rest of the team to confirm."
answers.explanation_why: Although the student is acknowledging the need to discuss with the team, they should not disclose the result to the patient before consulting with the senior team members. In addition, the patient's medical information should not be shared in a public space such as the hospital cafeteria. Finally, this can cause psychological harm to the patient as he will likely be worried the whole time while waiting for the confirmation of the results.

answers.content: "Unfortunately, the biopsy is consistent with cancer and your prognosis is poor since it indicates metastasis."
answers.explanation_why: Although the student already knows the result of the biopsy and it is important to be honest with the patient, it is unlikely that the student can provide the most accurate and complete information about the topic. Therefore, it would not be appropriate for the student to disclose the information to the patient in this situation. Moreover, medical information should not be disclosed in public spaces such as the hospital cafeteria.

answers.content: "The result is back but I need to discuss it with the team before I can give you accurate information."
answers.explanation_why: Medical students are often confronted with situations in which patients ask them to disclose diagnostic workup, treatment options, or information on prognosis. The result of the biopsy should not be disclosed until the student is able to discuss it with senior members of the team, because medical students are not qualified to provide the most accurate and detailed information about complex topics. The student must also be honest with the patient, acknowledging that the information requested is available and explaining why its disclosure is being withheld. Finally, the cafeteria is not an appropriate environment to deliver clinical information to the patient. Clinical information should be disclosed in an environment in which privacy, time, and emotional support can be ensured.

answers.content: "I do not know if the biopsy result is back but I will get back to you."
answers.explanation_why: The student must be honest with the patient, and they already know the result of the patient's biopsy. Lying to the patient violates the principle of honesty.

answers.content: "Let's go back to your room so it's more private and I will go over the result with you."
answers.explanation_why: When disclosing a patient's medical information, one should look for an appropriate environment to deliver it to the patient, in which privacy, time, and emotional support can be ensured. However, it is not appropriate for the student to disclose the results at this time because medical students are not qualified to provide the most accurate and complete information about complex topics.

question_text: Two researchers wish to determine the prevalence of hypertension in a metropolitan city. The first researcher measured the blood pressure from 1032 inpatients at a tertiary care hospital for geriatric patients in the city (study A). The second researcher performed community blood pressure screening on 1003 people (study B) through simple random sampling. Both studies are conducted using calibrated sphygmomanometers from the same manufacturer. Compared to study A, the result of study B is most likely to have which of the following properties with respect to each researcher's initial goal?
content_preview: Two researchers wish to determine the prevalence of hypertension in a metropolitan city. The first researcher measured the blood pressure from 1032 inpatients at a tertiary care hospital for geriatric patients in the city (study A). The second researcher performed community blood pressure screening on 1003 people (study B) through simple random sampling. Both studies are conducted using calibrated sphygmomanometers from the same manufacturer. Compared to study A, the result of study B is most likely to have which of the following properties with respect to each researcher's initial goal?
hint: Study A exhibits Berkson bias because its patients are selected from a subpopulation (tertiary care hospital) rather than the city's general population.
learning_objective: Interpret the impact of study population selection on research validity, and choose the property that reflects higher external validity.

answers.explanation_why: A study's accuracy (validity) depends on systematic errors and bias. The two forms of validity are internal and external. Internal validity is likely unaffected by the blood pressure measurement, as both studies use calibrated sphygmomanometers from the same manufacturer. External validity refers to how applicable the study is to the general population; study B is more likely to exhibit higher external validity compared to study A, which involves Berkson bias. In study A, the actual prevalence of hypertension in the general population is less likely to be accurately reflected due to this bias. Therefore, study B is expected to have higher accuracy.

images.title: Reliability and validity
images.description: Illustration of the principles of reliability (precision) and validity (accuracy)The crosses represent data points from repeated measurements taken using the same instrument, and the target represents the true value of the attribute being measured.Reliability refers to how similar the data points are to each other: when reliability is low, the data points are more widely dispersed. When reliability is high, the data points are more close together.Validity refers to how close the data points are to the true value: when validity is low, the data points do not approximate the true value.

answers.explanation_why: Precision (reliability) is the reproducibility of test results on the same sample under similar conditions. Precision depends on random errors that occur by chance (e.g., unpredictable fluctuations in blood pressure). These errors can be reduced by repeating measurements and/or increasing sample size. Precision is unlikely to be affected here, as the sample size of study B is similar to the one of study A. In addition, the measurement of blood pressure is performed similarly in both studies.

answers.content: Lower risk of a type I error
answers.explanation_why: A type I error occurs in hypothesis testing when the null hypothesis is incorrectly rejected and the alternative one is accepted, although the observed effect is due to chance. As these are independent cross-sectional studies without a comparison arm, there is no null hypothesis to reject.

Measurement bias is caused by inconsistencies in measurement or classification between sample groups. Measurement bias can be caused by human error or instrument error. In this case, an example of measurement bias would be using a defective sphygmomanometer. There is no indication to suspect measurement bias in the described studies. Instead, this study exhibits Berkson bias, which is a selection, not a measurement, bias.

Statistical power is the probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true. Because these are two independent cross-sectional studies without a comparison arm, there is no null hypothesis to reject.

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of behavior they find worrying. One week ago, he was suspended from school after talking back to his teacher and preventing her from finishing the class. He also refused to wait outside the principal's office because he says, the principal “is stupid.” This was his 3^rd suspension in 8 months. He frequently argues with his parents and does not respect their curfews. They have tried grounding him, but he keeps escaping through the window at night and does not answer his phone. When his parents try to confront him, he loses his temper and starts screaming at them. During the interview, the patient refuses to answer and frequently disrupts the physician. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of behavior they find worrying. One week ago, he was suspended from school after talking back to his teacher and preventing her from finishing the class. He also refused to wait outside the principal's office because he says, the principal “is stupid.” This was his 3rd suspension in 8 months. He frequently argues with his parents and does not respect their curfews. They have tried grounding him, but he keeps escaping through the window at night and does not answer his phone. When his parents try to confront him, he loses his temper and starts screaming at them. During the interview, the patient refuses to answer and frequently disrupts the physician. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This teenager shows overly disruptive behavior toward adults.
learning_objective: Recognize oppositional defiant disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) is characterized by anger, irritable mood, and defiant behavior toward authority figures and peers that significantly impairs social and/or academic functioning for ≥ 6 months, as is the case here. Individuals with ODD have impaired function in multiple environments (e.g., social, educational, occupational), and they typically express hostility toward individuals within their immediate social circles (e.g., family members, peers, work colleagues, teachers). Treatment options include psychotherapy (individual and family), parent management training, and social skills programs.

Disruptive behavior and occasional temper tantrums are normal manifestations of adolescent development. However, such behavior is considered pathological when it is frequent, persistent, and/or impairs the patient's ability to function normally in daily life (e.g., interacting with peers, teachers, parents).

Intermittent explosive disorder can manifest with sudden aggressive verbal outbursts disproportionate to the trigger for ≥ 3 months, which can lead to consequences such as being suspended from school, as seen here. However, patients with intermittent explosive disorder typically show remorse, regret, or embarrassment after their outbursts, which this patient does not. Moreover, patients with intermittent explosive disorder are prone to self-harm, and no self-harm has been observed in this patient.

Antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) typically manifests with aggressive and impulsive behavior and repeated failures to fulfill obligations (e.g., complete schoolwork), similar to what is seen in this patient. However, additional features, such as engaging in criminal activity, disregarding personal safety and/or the safety of others, and manipulating others would also be expected in ASPD, and none of these features are seen here. Moreover, while affected individuals may develop symptoms in adolescence, the diagnosis of antisocial personality disorder cannot be made until the patient is 18 years of age.

Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) can manifest with recurrent temper tantrums both at home and at school, as seen here. However, patients with DMDD display extreme temper outbursts that are out of proportion to the inciting event and are persistently angry or irritable between these outbursts, which is not the case for this patient. Moreover, a diagnosis of DMDD cannot be made unless the symptoms have persisted for ≥ 12 months and the onset of symptoms occurs before 10 years of age.

Conduct disorder (CD) manifests with aggression towards others and disruptive behavior at home and school, as seen in this patient. However, patients with CD also have repetitive and persistent behavior that violates important age-appropriate societal norms and the basic rights of others (e.g., stealing, property destruction, violence). Moreover, a diagnosis of CD cannot be made unless the symptoms have been ongoing for ≥ 12 months.
