question_text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, he was started on increasing doses of risperidone because of behavioral changes. His mother now reports that he has become increasingly suspicious of the mail carrier, who he believes is “a secret agent from the CIA who is spying on our family.” The patient has been hospitalized for similar episodes in the past. He is currently at the maximum dose of risperidone. Previous treatment with quetiapine was not effective. His mother reports that he has been living with her since he lost his job 3 months ago. His mother has seen him taking his medications regularly. Last month, his girlfriend left him after he attacked her because he believed that she was cheating on him. He used to smoke marijuana on a regular basis but stopped 1 year ago. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. He appears agitated. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he does not respond to any questions or instructions and continues to look to the left while nodding and smiling. Laboratory studies, including a urine toxicology screen, show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 24-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, he was started on increasing doses of risperidone because of behavioral changes. His mother now reports that he has become increasingly suspicious of the mail carrier, who he believes is “a secret agent from the CIA who is spying on our family.” The patient has been hospitalized for similar episodes in the past. He is currently at the maximum dose of risperidone. Previous treatment with quetiapine was not effective. His mother reports that he has been living with her since he lost his job 3 months ago. His mother has seen him taking his medications regularly. Last month, his girlfriend left him after he attacked her because he believed that she was cheating on him. He used to smoke marijuana on a regular basis but stopped 1 year ago. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. He appears agitated. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he does not respond to any questions or instructions and continues to look to the left while nodding and smiling. Laboratory studies, including a urine toxicology screen, show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient most likely has treatment-resistant schizophrenia, which is defined as ongoing positive symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations) despite two antipsychotic trials of ≥ 6 weeks at the maximum dose.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate antipsychotic therapy for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.

answers.explanation_why: Long-term injectable (depot form) antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) may be considered in patients with schizophrenia with poor treatment adherence. This patient takes his medication regularly and, therefore, would not benefit from long-term injectable haloperidol.

Clozapine is usually the first-line therapy for treatment-resistant schizophrenia because it is more effective than other antipsychotics. Clozapine is associated with an increased risk of agranulocytosis. Therefore, the benefits and risks of treatment, as well as the patient's ability to adhere to treatment and follow-ups, must be weighed and discussed with the patient and their family. Before initiating clozapine, the leukocyte count and differential should also be assessed; regular monitoring is indicated during treatment. Patients should have an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) > 1500 cells/μL before beginning treatment with clozapine. Additionally, monitoring for adverse metabolic effects (e.g., weight gain, hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia) is also recommended since atypical antipsychotics also increase the risk of metabolic syndrome.

Electroconvulsive therapy and antipsychotic therapy are indicated for treatment-resistant schizophrenia in patients with low absolute neutrophil counts and for schizophrenia with catatonia, neither of which is the case here.

Oral lithium is a mood stabilizer that is indicated for both the acute and long-term management of mania. Although this patient is agitated and distracted, he lacks additional symptoms of mania (e.g., flight of ideas, elevated mood). Occasionally, other mood stabilizers, like lamotrigine, are used in combination with antipsychotics in patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia. However, oral lithium is not the first-line therapy in the management of such patients.

answers.content: Discontinue medication and refer for cognitive behavioral therapy
answers.explanation_why: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be used in combination with antipsychotic drugs in patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia. However, CBT is less effective when used alone.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like fluoxetine can be used to treat schizophrenic patients with concurrent depression or anxiety, neither of which is seen in this man. This patient has treatment-resistant schizophrenia, for which SSRIs are not effective.

question_text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son for the evaluation of occasional epigastric pain, nausea, and weight loss for the past 2 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and a history of recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. Ten years ago, the patient was diagnosed with brief psychotic disorder after the death of his wife. Since then, his mental status has been stable. He lives alone and takes care of all his activities of daily living. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks two glasses of wine daily. His current medication is metformin. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a pancreatic mass. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a suspicious mass in the head of the pancreas that is classified as unresectable. A needle biopsy specimen of the mass confirms a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. When the doctor wants to enter the patient's room to reveal the diagnosis to the patient, he is approached by the son who says, “If it's cancer, please don't tell him.” Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the physician?
content_preview: A 75-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son for the evaluation of occasional epigastric pain, nausea, and weight loss for the past 2 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and a history of recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. Ten years ago, the patient was diagnosed with brief psychotic disorder after the death of his wife. Since then, his mental status has been stable. He lives alone and takes care of all his activities of daily living. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks two glasses of wine daily. His current medication is metformin. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a pancreatic mass. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a suspicious mass in the head of the pancreas that is classified as unresectable. A needle biopsy specimen of the mass confirms a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. When the doctor wants to enter the patient's room to reveal the diagnosis to the patient, he is approached by the son who says, “If it's cancer, please don't tell him.” Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the physician?
hint: A patient with decision-making capacity has the right to full medical disclosure unless there is a good reason to withhold information.
learning_objective: Recognize the patient's right to medical disclosure, and choose the appropriate response to family requests for nondisclosure.

answers.content: "I will respect your wish to withhold the diagnosis from your father."
answers.explanation_why: Patients with decision-making capacity have the right to full disclosure and, therefore, the right to know their diagnosis based on the principle of autonomy. Because there is no evidence to suggest that this patient lacks decision-making capacity, the son does not have the right to make medical decisions for his father.

answers.content: "I can help you disclose the diagnosis to your father. He has a right to know."
answers.explanation_why: The physician has a duty to directly disclose a diagnosis to a patient. Transferring this responsibility to a relative of the patient is inappropriate and unprofessional. It can, however, be beneficial to include family members in the discussion to bridge any communication gaps or for emotional support, as long as the patient has consented to the physician disclosing health information to family members.

answers.content: "Can you tell me why you don't want your father to know about the diagnosis?"
answers.explanation_why: Patient autonomy is one of the four core principles of medical ethics. When a patient's family or friends make a request for nondisclosure, it is critical to understand why the request has been made because this will inform physicians of how best to approach disclosure while respecting cultural differences or other concerns. Understanding the motivation behind such requests may also uncover explicit reasons not to tell the patient (e.g., grounds for invoking therapeutic privilege, patient preference to not know the diagnosis). Furthermore, it promotes rapport and a trusting relationship with the family. In most cases, cognitively intact patients should be informed of the diagnosis so that they can make appropriate medical decisions. Practical approaches to disclosing a sensitive diagnosis include understanding the patient's preference and incremental disclosure (SPIKES protocol).

answers.content: "As his physician, I cannot withhold any information about your father's health from him."
answers.explanation_why: Cognitively intact patients have the right to know their diagnosis. However, the son's request for nondisclosure raises concern for cultural or personal considerations that the physician might be unaware of. In addition, disregard for the son's request may hurt any established or potential physician-family relationship that could be beneficial moving forward. Other approaches should be considered before disclosing the diagnosis to the patient.

answers.content: "I propose a psychiatric consultation to assess your father's mental competence."
answers.explanation_why: A psychiatric consultation is beneficial to patients with active psychiatric conditions that might undermine or interfere with their decision-making capacity. For patients with a psychiatric history, engaging their primary psychiatrist can help to ascertain their baseline capacity. Although this patient has a history of psychiatric illness, his mental status is currently stable and there is no other evidence to suggest that a psychiatric disorder is impairing his decision-making. A psychiatric consultation at this time would not be appropriate.

question_text: An 18-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of vision problems. He recently enlisted in the US Army and started military training 2 weeks ago, but was not able to continue because his vision became severely blurry. He ambulates with a walking cane and wears dark glasses. He has no personal history of serious illness. His father has hyperopia. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Inspection of the eyes shows no abnormalities. Fundoscopy findings are normal. Snellen eye chart examination shows a visual acuity of 20/200 on the right and 20/100 on the left. When the physician suddenly passes a hand in front of the patient's eyes, he starts blinking. When asked to close his eyes, extend his hands, and touch the tip of his nose with his index finger, the patient touches his eyebrow and chin instead of his nose. The remainder of the neurologic examination is unremarkable. When asked to perform an additional perimetry test, the patient says “I'm really tired at this point and would really like to go home. I would really appreciate it if you could verify that I cannot see and that I cannot continue the military training.” In addition to acknowledging the patient's concerns, which of the following is the most appropriate action from the physician?
content_preview: An 18-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of vision problems. He recently enlisted in the US Army and started military training 2 weeks ago, but was not able to continue because his vision became severely blurry. He ambulates with a walking cane and wears dark glasses. He has no personal history of serious illness. His father has hyperopia. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Inspection of the eyes shows no abnormalities. Fundoscopy findings are normal. Snellen eye chart examination shows a visual acuity of 20/200 on the right and 20/100 on the left. When the physician suddenly passes a hand in front of the patient's eyes, he starts blinking. When asked to close his eyes, extend his hands, and touch the tip of his nose with his index finger, the patient touches his eyebrow and chin instead of his nose. The remainder of the neurologic examination is unremarkable. When asked to perform an additional perimetry test, the patient says “I'm really tired at this point and would really like to go home. I would really appreciate it if you could verify that I cannot see and that I cannot continue the military training.” In addition to acknowledging the patient's concerns, which of the following is the most appropriate action from the physician?
hint: This patient's physical examination findings (abnormal finger-to-nose test indicating a cerebellar condition, eye blinking as a response to a sudden hand wave indicating intact visual pathway) do not correlate with his presenting symptom (blurry vision) and additional examination findings (poor visual acuity indicating defective visual pathway). In combination with his request for a letter excusing him from military training, this should raise concern for malingering.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of malingering, and choose the appropriate management strategy.

answers.explanation_why: Meeting on a regular basis in order to build a collaborative patient-physician relationship is important for patients with somatic symptom disorder, a mental disorder in which patients experience various somatic symptoms resulting in significant distress. However, this patient's presentation suggests that he is malingering, which is not a psychiatric disorder, but rather an intentional behavior motivated by an external reward (e.g., avoiding work, obtaining insurance money). It would be inappropriate to schedule follow-up meetings without addressing his malingering behavior.

answers.content: Initiate a discussion about the patient's recent enlistment to the military
answers.explanation_why: Initiating a discussion about his recent enlistment to the military in a calm, distant, yet empathetic manner gives the patient the opportunity to be honest without becoming uncomfortable and possibly compromising the patient-physician relationship. Malingering individuals are often noncompliant and insist on undergoing extensive medical evaluation. Unnecessary referrals should be avoided because they perpetuate malingering, which is a behavior and not a psychiatric disorder.

answers.content: Provide the patient with an exemption letter for military service
answers.explanation_why: Acknowledging the patient's vision loss and writing an exemption letter for military training would reward and perpetuate his malingering behavior.

answers.content: Refer the patient to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation
answers.explanation_why: Acknowledging the patient's vision loss and referring him to an ophthalmologist would be indicated if a medical condition of the visual pathway was suspected. No medical conditions of the visual pathway are suspected in this patient, so this action would not be appropriate.

answers.content: Educate the patient about his diagnosis
answers.explanation_why: Patient education is the first-line treatment for functional neurological symptom disorder, a mental disorder that can manifest with vision loss without evidence of a defective visual pathway. This patient is most likely malingering, which is not a psychiatric diagnosis but rather an intentional behavior motivated by an external reward (e.g., avoiding work, obtaining insurance money), so patient education would not be appropriate.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department and demands to speak to a doctor immediately without giving any further explanation. When being asked to wait, she briefly sits down before restlessly pacing the room. The patient's medical history is unknown. She appears agitated. She is alert and oriented to person and place. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Initial examination shows dilated pupils that are equal in size and reactive to light. The patient refuses to participate in any further medical examinations. When a nurse attempts to talk to her, she briskly stands up and says to the nurse “I'll kill you if you don't let me speak to a doctor.” The patient remains aggressive despite attempts at deescalation, and she is subsequently physically restrained and chemically sedated with an intramuscular lorazepam injection. In addition to continuous observation of the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department and demands to speak to a doctor immediately without giving any further explanation. When being asked to wait, she briefly sits down before restlessly pacing the room. The patient's medical history is unknown. She appears agitated. She is alert and oriented to person and place. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Initial examination shows dilated pupils that are equal in size and reactive to light. The patient refuses to participate in any further medical examinations. When a nurse attempts to talk to her, she briskly stands up and says to the nurse “I'll kill you if you don't let me speak to a doctor.” The patient remains aggressive despite attempts at deescalation, and she is subsequently physically restrained and chemically sedated with an intramuscular lorazepam injection. In addition to continuous observation of the patient, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with psychomotor agitation and combative behavior. The cause of her symptoms is not known.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step after sedating an agitated patient.

answers.content: Reevaluate the patient when she is no longer sedated
answers.explanation_why: An agitated patient that shows violent behavior and poses an imminent threat to themself or others can be physically restrained and/or chemically sedated if other deescalation methods (e.g., verbal techniques) are unsuccessful. After the patient has calmed down or adequate sedation has been achieved, restraints should be removed immediately. Once the patient is no longer sedated, the physician should then reevaluate the underlying cause of the patient's behavior and decision-making capacity to determine whether she should be admitted or discharged. Admission is appropriate when imminent harm to one's self or others continues and/or if the patient is uncooperative, intoxicated, or demonstrates psychotic behavior. If the patient is no longer combative, the behavior was a result of intoxication, and medical examination finds no abnormalities, discharge is recommended.

Involuntary admission is appropriate if the patient poses danger to self or others, is in grave disability (e.g., due to a psychiatric illness), or is in need of acute medical treatment. Although involuntary admission may be appropriate in this case, another step needs to be taken before a decision to admit the patient can be made.

It is appropriate to notify law enforcement authorities when an individual poses a serious and imminent threat to a person or the public. Although this patient verbally threatened a staff member, no physical harm occurred and she has already been physically restrained and chemically sedated. She does not pose a serious or imminent threat anymore, so it would not be appropriate to notify law enforcement.

answers.content: Restrain the patient until a court order is obtained
answers.explanation_why: It is inappropriate and illegal to prolong physical and/or chemical restraint of a patient after the patient has calmed down or sedation has been achieved. Moreover, it is not necessary to obtain a court order to physically restrain and/or chemically sedate a patient that poses an immediate threat of danger to self or others.

question_text: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for glycemic control. She recently emigrated from Russia. She does not speak English and asks her bilingual adult daughter to translate. Her hemoglobin A_1C is 9.1%. A physician notices that the average hemoglobin A_1C of patients with diabetes mellitus and limited English proficiency in the hospital is significantly higher when compared to patients proficient in English. The hospital conducts an inpatient study, which finds a statistically significant correlation between scores on a standardized verbal English proficiency test and scores on standardized medication adherence scales and patient-physician concordance scales. Based on the results of a subsequent root cause analysis, the hospital management renegotiates health care payment contracts with their insurance provider to allow for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services. This intervention best addresses which of the following barriers to high-quality health care?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for glycemic control. She recently emigrated from Russia. She does not speak English and asks her bilingual adult daughter to translate. Her hemoglobin A1C is 9.1%. A physician notices that the average hemoglobin A1C of patients with diabetes mellitus and limited English proficiency in the hospital is significantly higher when compared to patients proficient in English. The hospital conducts an inpatient study, which finds a statistically significant correlation between scores on a standardized verbal English proficiency test and scores on standardized medication adherence scales and patient-physician concordance scales. Based on the results of a subsequent root cause analysis, the hospital management renegotiates health care payment contracts with their insurance provider to allow for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services. This intervention best addresses which of the following barriers to high-quality health care?
hint: The intervention (i.e., resource allocation) for patients with limited English proficiency (LEP) was undertaken by the hospital to prevent poor health outcomes as a result of inequitable access to care.
learning_objective: Recognize the healthcare disparity caused by inequitable allocation of healthcare resources.

answers.explanation_why: Information bias is a systemic research error caused by inconsistencies in measurement and/or classification between sample groups. This bias can be corrected by using standardized data collection techniques. Information bias is not a barrier to high-quality health care in this scenario, and it cannot be addressed by allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services.

Distributive injustice, a result of inequitable access to care, is a barrier to high-quality health care. Patients with LEP are at high risk of experiencing distributive injustice, which can cause patient-physician discordance and medication nonadherence, as seen here. Allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services facilitates equitable access to care, which contributes to the correction of distributive injustice.

Health illiteracy, which is primarily due to the complexity of health care information and health care systems, is a barrier to high-quality health care but is distinct from LEP. Patients of all ethnicities, languages, and cultures can be affected by health illiteracy. Conversely, a patient with LEP can have a high level of health literacy in their native language. The use of professional medical interpreter services helps patients with LEP to receive information from health care providers in their native language but it does not address health illiteracy per se since the translated information can still be complex. Simplifying information (e.g., avoiding technical medical jargon, breaking down instructions into simple steps) is an intervention to improve health literacy.

Identity devaluation (i.e., relational injustice) is a barrier to high-quality health care. Patients with LEP may experience identity devaluation due to incorrect assumptions by caregivers (e.g., about the patient's intelligence) or broader cultural incongruities. Identity devaluation can be corrected by systemic changes that increase intercultural understanding, such as hiring more bilingual physicians. Allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services does not increase intercultural understanding per se because it does not improve health care providers' intercultural competence.

The availability heuristic, a type of cognitive bias, is the tendency to consider past events perceived as significant or readily recalled information as more representative of the truth than events perceived as insignificant or information that comes to mind less promptly. Availability heuristics can be a barrier to high-quality health care because they result in diagnostic errors by health care providers and in medication nonadherence by patients. The availability heuristic is unrelated to a patient's English proficiency, and allowing for reimbursement of professional medical interpreter services will not address this cognitive bias.

question_text: A 79-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter out of concern for memory loss. He previously worked in finance but now requires help paying his bills. One month ago, he got lost in his own neighborhood and could not find his way home. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurocognitive testing shows he is alert and oriented to person and place but does not know the year or month. During the examination, the physician names three unrelated objects clearly and slowly. The physician then immediately asks the patient to repeat the names of all three objects. Which of the following cognitive domains is being tested by the described task?
content_preview: A 79-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter out of concern for memory loss. He previously worked in finance but now requires help paying his bills. One month ago, he got lost in his own neighborhood and could not find his way home. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurocognitive testing shows he is alert and oriented to person and place but does not know the year or month. During the examination, the physician names three unrelated objects clearly and slowly. The physician then immediately asks the patient to repeat the names of all three objects. Which of the following cognitive domains is being tested by the described task?
hint: This physician is performing a test of the patient's immediate memory.
learning_objective: Recall the tests for immediate, short-term, and long-term memory.

answers.explanation_why: Orientation is the cognitive awareness of person, place, and time, and it is tested by assessing a patient's ability to recognize themselves (e.g., name), the time (e.g., month, day, year), and their physical location (e.g., city, state, country). For example, this patient is oriented to person and place but does not know the month or year. This patient, however, is being asked to perform a test of immediate memory.

The task of repeating three objects immediately after they have been named is a test of registration (also known as immediate memory or immediate recall). Registration is the shortest type of information storage. Registration is distinct from recent memory (also known as short-term memory), in which information is stored and then reproduced at a later point (e.g., naming the objects and then asking five minutes later for them to be repeated). Remote memory (also known as long-term memory) refers to memory of the distant past.

Remote memory (also known as long-term memory) refers to memory of the distant past. An example of testing this cognitive domain is asking the patient to remember something that occurred years ago. This patient, however, is being asked to perform a test of immediate memory.
Affect is an assessment of the type, range, and appropriateness of emotional expression based on the physician's observation of facial and bodily gestures, and tone of speech.

The task of naming the objects and then asking the patient five minutes later for them to be repeated is a test of short-term memory. This patient, however, is being asked to perform a test of immediate memory.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 0, at 30 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Prenatal care for the current pregnancy was initiated late and she has missed several prenatal visits. She is not adherent to the micronutrient supplementation prescribed by the physician. She has a history of 3 medical abortions. Her medical history is remarkable for several visits to the emergency department over the past 5 years for nonspecific complaints. She is usually accompanied by her husband but has come in alone today. She appears anxious, has a tearful affect, and avoids eye contact. She denies any suicidal ideation. Physical examination shows multiple bruises of different ages on her forearms. When asked about the findings, the patient replies that she bruises easily. The remainder of the examination and the laboratory study results, including a complete blood count and coagulation studies, show no abnormalities. When asked if she feels safe in her relationship, the patient responds, “We have had our difficulties, like anyone, but my husband is a good man.” In addition to counseling and psychological support, which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 0, at 30 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Prenatal care for the current pregnancy was initiated late and she has missed several prenatal visits. She is not adherent to the micronutrient supplementation prescribed by the physician. She has a history of 3 medical abortions. Her medical history is remarkable for several visits to the emergency department over the past 5 years for nonspecific complaints. She is usually accompanied by her husband but has come in alone today. She appears anxious, has a tearful affect, and avoids eye contact. She denies any suicidal ideation. Physical examination shows multiple bruises of different ages on her forearms. When asked about the findings, the patient replies that she bruises easily. The remainder of the examination and the laboratory study results, including a complete blood count and coagulation studies, show no abnormalities. When asked if she feels safe in her relationship, the patient responds, “We have had our difficulties, like anyone, but my husband is a good man.” In addition to counseling and psychological support, which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
hint: Late initiation of prenatal care, missed appointments, medication nonadherence, multiple abortions, injuries of different ages, and frequent visits to the emergency department should raise suspicion for intimate partner violence (IPV), which often becomes more severe during pregnancy and the postpartum period.
learning_objective: Recognize signs of intimate partner violence, and choose the appropriate resources to offer the patient.

answers.content: Inquire about access to a shelter
answers.explanation_why:
Individuals experiencing IPV are at high risk of health impairment (e.g., injury, preterm birth, death) and should be provided with information about in-house and community resources (e.g., shelters). Risk factors for escalation should be evaluated (e.g., partner being abusive during pregnancy, victim attempting to leave their partner) and a safety plan should be established with the patient before they leave the office. This plan typically includes advising the patient to prepare an emergency kit that contains important items (e.g., documents, money), which should be stored outside the home, defining a place to go to in case of an emergency (e.g., a shelter), setting up an alarm signal for contact persons (e.g., neighbors) to call emergency services, and advising the patient to avoid areas of increased risk at home in times of escalating violence (e.g., the kitchen, where knives are stored).

Screening for IPV is recommended in all women of reproductive age. If the partner is present during the patient interview, it is important to first separate the patient from the partner before addressing suspected IPV as confrontation in front of the partner can endanger the patient. Requirements for reporting IPV vary by state. Reporting IPV to law enforcement is mandatory in most states if there is evidence of weapon injury or imminent danger. If there is no such evidence, patient consent is necessary before reporting the case to authorities. If children are involved, reporting to child protective services is often mandatory. If the patient is an at-risk adult, reporting to adult protective services may be required.

answers.content: Encourage the patient to leave their partner
answers.explanation_why: Patients with suspected IPV should generally not be encouraged to leave their partners. Many patients are not ready to leave their partners because of financial or family dependencies, feelings of guilt, or fear of retaliation. Pressuring the patient to leave their partner may weaken the patient-physician relationship. If a patient discloses abuse by a partner, a different action is more appropriate.

Reporting abuse to Adult Protective Services is mandatory in most states in cases of abuse of vulnerable adults (e.g., disabled individuals, elderly individuals). In cases of IPV affecting adults who are not considered vulnerable, reporting regulations vary between states. If there is evidence or threat of injury from a weapon, law enforcement must be notified in most states. This patient, however, shows no evidence of injury from a weapon. Furthermore, pregnant women have full decision-making capacity and patient consent is required to report cases like this one if there is no evidence of imminent danger. Another step is more appropriate at this time.

answers.content: Revisit the topic of intimate partner violence at the next visit
answers.explanation_why: Prenatal care provides an opportunity for close follow-up of IPV and for assuring ongoing support by the provider. However, because this patient has already missed several prenatal appointments and had several visits to the emergency department, IPV should be addressed immediately. To best protect the safety of the patient and her unborn child, a different action is more appropriate.

Involuntary admission may become necessary in patients with severe psychiatric disorders who require medical treatment, have signs of grave disability (e.g., unable to maintain sufficient food, clothing, or shelter), or are a danger to themselves or others. Since this patient shows no evidence of a mental illness that would endanger herself or others, another step is more appropriate at this time.

question_text: The chief medical officer at an obstetrics and gynecology clinic has noticed an increased refusal rate for the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine among teenage girls over the past 6 months. The chief medical officer meets with all physicians who provide vaccination counseling and performs mock consultations for training. In response to a simulated patient query about the risk of syncope from the quadrivalent HPV vaccine, an attending physician who has experienced very low rates of vaccination refusal says, “More than 99.99% of patients who received the quadrivalent vaccine did not report any adverse effects and only 0.008% of patients who received the quadrivalent vaccine had significant lightheadedness.” In response to the same query, an intern who has experienced comparatively higher rates of vaccination refusal says, “Approximately 50 in 100,000 patients who receive the quadrivalent vaccine report at least one adverse effect, and approximately 15% of those who reported an adverse effect had significant lightheadedness as one of the adverse effects.” When compared to the attending physician's response, which of the following types of cognitive bias is most likely to affect a patient who hears the intern's response?
content_preview: The chief medical officer at an obstetrics and gynecology clinic has noticed an increased refusal rate for the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine among teenage girls over the past 6 months. The chief medical officer meets with all physicians who provide vaccination counseling and performs mock consultations for training. In response to a simulated patient query about the risk of syncope from the quadrivalent HPV vaccine, an attending physician who has experienced very low rates of vaccination refusal says, “More than 99.99% of patients who received the quadrivalent vaccine did not report any adverse effects and only 0.008% of patients who received the quadrivalent vaccine had significant lightheadedness.” In response to the same query, an intern who has experienced comparatively higher rates of vaccination refusal says, “Approximately 50 in 100,000 patients who receive the quadrivalent vaccine report at least one adverse effect, and approximately 15% of those who reported an adverse effect had significant lightheadedness as one of the adverse effects.” When compared to the attending physician's response, which of the following types of cognitive bias is most likely to affect a patient who hears the intern's response?
hint: Both the attending physician and the intern present the same information. However, the intern's phrasing of the response, which focuses more on the vaccine's negative outcomes, might influence patients' decision-making process and lead to vaccination refusal.
learning_objective: Recall the concept of framing bias in patient communication.

answers.explanation_why:
Framing bias is the tendency for an individual's conclusions to be unduly influenced by the way information is presented (“framed”). The framing bias in this scenario is the result of a heuristic that makes people prefer an option when its positive aspects (positive frame) are highlighted and its negative ones (negative frame) are minimized (e.g., "glass half full" vs. “glass half empty”). The consequences of framing biases should be considered during patient counseling and when formulating public health messages. When using a shared decision-making strategy, the effects of framing bias can be minimized by providing both the positive and negative frames, and by using patient decision aids.

Cognitive biases can also affect health care providers. For example, the phrasing or order of presentation of information in electronic health records or during patient handovers and patient interviews can emphasize one aspect of the patient's health information over another aspect and lead to diagnostic errors as a result of a framing bias.

Availability bias is the tendency to consider past events perceived as significant or readily recalled information as more representative of the truth than events perceived as insignificant or information that comes to mind less promptly. An example of availability bias would be a situation in which a patient refuses HPV vaccination after hearing about a friend who experiences syncope following HPV vaccination and fails to consider all the individuals who have not experienced any adverse event after HPV vaccination.

Visceral bias refers to a tendency to allow positive or negative feelings to influence decision-making. An example of visceral bias would be a situation in which a patient refuses HPV vaccination because the patient mistrusts the physician as a result of transference.

Confirmation bias is the tendency for an individual to selectively seek and emphasize information that supports their prior conclusion and overlook information that goes against the conclusion. An example of confirmation bias is a situation in which a patient who already believes that HPV vaccination is harmful selectively reads up on adverse events following HPV vaccination.

Anchoring bias is the tendency for an individual to stick ("anchor") to a prior conclusion even when new information that goes against this conclusion is presented. An example of an anchoring bias is a situation in which a patient who believes that HPV vaccination is harmful does not change their mind even when the physician presents information supporting the safety and efficacy of HPV vaccination.

question_text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician as a new patient and requests a whole-body CT scan for cancer screening because she can feel that “there is something in her body.” Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. She has had several jobs over the past 10 years but is currently unemployed and has Medicaid insurance. There is no family history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient explains that she has seen several physicians in the past, but all of them refused to order the requested test for her. She says, “You seem wonderful, unlike my previous physicians. They were all incompetent. I even filed a lawsuit against one of them!” On exploring the patient's fear of cancer and the reasons for her inquiry, she reports that she saw an online direct-to-consumer advertisement about whole-body CT scans. The physician explains when whole-body CT scans are performed and why the test is not indicated in her case. The patient becomes agitated and insists that the physician order the test. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the patient's request?
content_preview: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician as a new patient and requests a whole-body CT scan for cancer screening because she can feel that “there is something in her body.” Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. She has had several jobs over the past 10 years but is currently unemployed and has Medicaid insurance. There is no family history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient explains that she has seen several physicians in the past, but all of them refused to order the requested test for her. She says, “You seem wonderful, unlike my previous physicians. They were all incompetent. I even filed a lawsuit against one of them!” On exploring the patient's fear of cancer and the reasons for her inquiry, she reports that she saw an online direct-to-consumer advertisement about whole-body CT scans. The physician explains when whole-body CT scans are performed and why the test is not indicated in her case. The patient becomes agitated and insists that the physician order the test. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the patient's request?
hint: This patient is asking for a cancer screening test that is not scientifically validated and not covered by her medical insurance. The physician should use a directive counseling approach when responding to her request.
learning_objective: Recognize when to reject a patient's request for nonindicated tests based on beneficence and nonmaleficence.

answers.content: "I understand that you are concerned about having cancer. I can order the test if you are willing to sign an against-medical-advice form."
answers.explanation_why: This response shows empathy and acknowledges the patient's concerns, which helps to build a trusting patient-physician relationship. However, regardless of whether the patient signs an against-medical-advice form, it is not appropriate for the physician to order a nonindicated, potentially harmful screening test.

answers.content: "A whole-body CT scan is associated with high levels of radiation exposure. I would instead recommend an MRI scan, which is a safer alternative."
answers.explanation_why: This response relies on the principle of shared-decision making, according to which patients and physicians decide on the best diagnostic and/or treatment option together. Although an MRI is not associated with radiation exposure and therefore has fewer potential risks than a CT scan, neither a CT scan nor an MRI is indicated in this case.

answers.content: "There is no indication that you might benefit from this test. I cannot in good conscience order the test for you at this time."
answers.explanation_why:
This response firmly yet politely rejects the patient's request. When evaluating a patient's demand for nonindicated care, physicians need to balance the core ethical principles. The ethical principle of patient autonomy, according to which a physician only assists in making decisions corresponding to the patient's personal values, is overruled in favor of beneficence and nonmaleficence in this directive counseling approach. Since there is no evidence that the possible benefits of whole-body CT scanning of asymptomatic individuals (e.g., to relieve the fear of cancer) outweigh the potential harm (e.g., radiation exposure, potential detection of ill-defined abnormalities requiring follow-up testing and interventions), the physician is acting in the patient's best interest (beneficence) and preventing harm (nonmaleficence). Moreover, denying nonindicated investigations and interventions also helps to ensure more equitable care. Finally, it is important for the physician to emphasize that the test is currently not indicated; it might be indicated in the future.

The patient's behavior in this scenario resembles splitting, a psychological defense mechanism characteristic of borderline personality disorder. Splitting involves separating experiences or people into all-good and all-bad, such as this patient's negative description of her past physicians. To minimize the effects of splitting, health care providers should collaborate toward common management goals, communicate regularly, and clarify their roles in patient care.

answers.content: "Unfortunately, your health insurance plan will not cover this test. Would you be willing to pay for it yourself?"
answers.explanation_why: Patients may require a test or treatment not covered by their insurance, in which case they should be informed about the option of paying for the service out of pocket. However, regardless of whether it is covered by her insurance, it is not appropriate for the physician to order a nonindicated, potentially harmful screening test.

answers.content: "I am sorry that there is nothing I can do for you at this point. If you insist on having the test, I think it would be best to see another physician."
answers.explanation_why: While physicians should always inform patients of their right to seek an additional medical opinion, it is not appropriate to threaten to end the patient-physician relationship because the patient insists on having a nonindicated test. Also, sending the patient to another physician will not solve the problem. Denying the request for a nonindicated screening test is the correct action, which is why the physician should refrain from apologizing. Finally, it is not true that the physician cannot do anything at this point, when the patient could be counseled on other aspects of health maintenance.

question_text: A 29-year-old man comes to the emergency department two hours after an episode of shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, and sweating. He did not cough blood during this episode. His symptoms resolved spontaneously after 15 minutes. He has no history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Medical history is significant for tobacco use disorder and panic disorder, for which the patient takes sertraline. He appears anxious. Pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is no leg asymmetry or edema. ECG is normal. The emergency room physician determines that the patient has a very low probability of having a pulmonary embolism, but decides to order a serum D-dimer test to evaluate for pulmonary embolism. The physician's decision was most likely subject to which of the following types of bias?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man comes to the emergency department two hours after an episode of shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, and sweating. He did not cough blood during this episode. His symptoms resolved spontaneously after 15 minutes. He has no history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Medical history is significant for tobacco use disorder and panic disorder, for which the patient takes sertraline. He appears anxious. Pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is no leg asymmetry or edema. ECG is normal. The emergency room physician determines that the patient has a very low probability of having a pulmonary embolism, but decides to order a serum D-dimer test to evaluate for pulmonary embolism. The physician's decision was most likely subject to which of the following types of bias?
hint: This patient's history of panic disorder and 15-minute episode of shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, and sweating indicates a panic attack.
learning_objective: Recall the definition of commission bias in clinical decision-making.

answers.explanation_why: Availability bias is the tendency to consider past events perceived as significant or readily recalled information as more representative of the truth than events perceived as insignificant or information that comes to mind less promptly. An example of availability bias would be a situation in which the physician orders serum D-dimer testing to rule out pulmonary embolism (PE) because he recently missed a diagnosis of PE in a different patient.

Visceral bias is the tendency for clinical decisions to be influenced by positive or negative feelings towards the patient. An example of visceral bias would be a situation in which the physician doubts the symptoms described by a patient with substance use disorder. There are no indications that the emergency room physician has any positive or negative feelings towards this man.

Confirmation bias (psychology) is the tendency to favor evidence that supports preconceived notions, ignoring other results. This physician ordered a D-dimer test to evaluate for pulmonary embolism (PE). There is no indication that he has preconceived expectations of PE and is now collecting evidence to confirm the diagnosis.

Gender bias occurs when assumptions about an individual are incorrectly based on the individual's real or perceived gender. This physician based the decision for D-dimer on the patient's presenting symptoms and concern about having a lung condition. There is no indication that the patient's gender had a significant influence on the physician's decision.

Commission bias is favoring action (e.g., ordering a D-dimer test) over inaction when inaction will likely lead to the same or a better outcome. This patient most likely has had a panic attack. His Wells score for pulmonary embolism (PE) indicates a low probability for PE and the pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (total score of 0 points) indicate that no further diagnostic testing is needed. Regardless of these facts, the physician has ordered a D-dimer test most likely as a result of a sense of obligation to the principle of beneficence.

Commission bias is less common in health care than omission bias, which is the tendency to prefer inaction over action.

hint: This patient's x-ray of the right knee shows a stress fracture in the medial proximal tibial metaphysis.
learning_objective: Recognize a stress fracture, and recall its risk factors.

answers.explanation_why: Morning stiffness can occur in osteoarthritis, which manifests with pain that worsens during or after exercise and is relieved with rest. However, x-rays in osteoarthritis typically show irregular joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and/or subchondral sclerosis, but not stress fractures. Additionally, osteoarthritis is most common in individuals aged > 50 years.

Night sweats and long-lasting bone pain can occur in infectious bone diseases (e.g., chronic osteomyelitis, bone tuberculosis) and in certain bone tumors (e.g., osteosarcoma). However, x-rays in chronic osteomyelitis show bone destruction, sequestrum formation, and/or periosteal reactions. In osteosarcoma, x-rays show lytic bone lesions adjacent to sclerotic lesions (moth-eaten appearance) and/or Codman triangles. Stress fractures are not typically seen in these diseases.

This patient may have received a fluoroquinolone for her recent urinary tract infection. One side effect of fluoroquinolones is tendinopathy, which causes pain that worsens with physical activity. However, fluoroquinolone tendinopathy most commonly affects the Achilles tendon and does not cause stress fractures of the tibia.

Repetitive microtrauma can cause bone remodeling, leading to stress fractures. Risk factors for stress fractures include female sex, prolonged periods of high-intensity activity (e.g., dancing) without adequate rest, and poor nutrition and/or low calorie intake. Many athletes have borderline low BMI and blood pressure as well as physiological sinus bradycardia. However, these findings in combination with xerosis and low body temperature raise suspicion for caloric restriction, which requires evaluation of dietary history.

Other risk factors for stress fractures include calcium and vitamin D deficiencies, improper technique during physical activity, and ill-fitting footwear.

Urinary symptoms such as foamy urine (due to proteinuria) can occur in multiple myeloma (MM), features of which include spontaneous fractures and bone pain. However, MM most commonly manifests with back pain, not limb pain, and with signs of anemia and hypercalcemia (e.g., constipation, muscle weakness). Additionally, x-rays in MM show lytic lesions, which appear as punched-out holes.

Cigarette smoking is a risk factor for osteoporosis, which can lead to stress fractures. However, the onset of osteoporosis typically occurs at 50–70 years of age. This patient's young age and other examination findings (e.g., bradycardia, low BMI) suggest another cause for reduced bone density.

images.title: Tibial stress fracture
images.description: X-ray right knee (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a patient with a history of atraumatic leg pain following intense exerciseAn irregular linear lucency (green overlay) accompanied by sclerosis (arrowheads) is seen in the medial proximal tibial metaphysis. The appearance is compatible with a stress fracture.The sensitivity of x-ray for the detection of early-stage stress fractures is low, although increases as the fracture heals. Examples of positive findings include a visible fracture line, sclerosis or cortical thickening, and periosteal reaction. MRI is the most sensitive modality for the detection of a stress fracture.

question_text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician because of concerns about his sexual performance for the past 3 years. The patient says that every time he sleeps with his life partner, within 30 seconds after penetration he has an orgasm which he cannot delay by any of the methods he has found on the internet. He has not had problems achieving an erection and cannot recall a triggering event for his concerns. Until now, he has never talked to a physician about his concerns because he feels embarrassed. He recently read in an article that approximately 1 in every 20 men experiences similar problems, which gave him the courage to come to the office today. He says that he cannot fully enjoy his sexual life and tries to avoid sexual intimacy although he feels attracted to his partner. He is happy with all other aspects of his relationship and personal life. He has hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Medications are chlorthalidone, losartan, and tamsulosin. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows no scrotal or penile abnormalities. In addition to recommending behavioral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician because of concerns about his sexual performance for the past 3 years. The patient says that every time he sleeps with his life partner, within 30 seconds after penetration he has an orgasm which he cannot delay by any of the methods he has found on the internet. He has not had problems achieving an erection and cannot recall a triggering event for his concerns. Until now, he has never talked to a physician about his concerns because he feels embarrassed. He recently read in an article that approximately 1 in every 20 men experiences similar problems, which gave him the courage to come to the office today. He says that he cannot fully enjoy his sexual life and tries to avoid sexual intimacy although he feels attracted to his partner. He is happy with all other aspects of his relationship and personal life. He has hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Medications are chlorthalidone, losartan, and tamsulosin. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows no scrotal or penile abnormalities. In addition to recommending behavioral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient fulfills the diagnostic criteria for premature ejaculation in the absence of erectile dysfunction. The next step in management takes advantage of the side effect profile of a specific drug.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for premature ejaculation.

answers.explanation_why: Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (PDE5 inhibitors) such as sildenafil can be used in patients with premature ejaculation who have concomitant erectile dysfunction. This patient has isolated premature ejaculation, for which sildenafil therapy is not indicated. Moreover, PDE5 inhibitors should be used with caution in patients who take alpha-receptor blockers, such as tamsulosin, because of a risk of orthostatic hypotension.

Tamsulosin is a sympatholytic drug used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Because of its sympatholytic properties, this drug can cause delayed ejaculation, as this process is stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system. Discontinuation is unlikely to provide any benefit to this patient with premature ejaculation.

Propranolol is a nonselective beta blocker that acts as a sympatholytic drug. Although ejaculation is primarily stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system, beta blockers do not play a role in the treatment of premature ejaculation. Beta blockers may cause erectile dysfunction, a different sexual disorder, and discontinuation of these drugs should be considered in patients with erectile dysfunction.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as paroxetine, are used first-line but off-label for the treatment of premature ejaculation in patients without concomitant erectile dysfunction. The indication takes advantage of the side effect profile of SSRIs, which includes ejaculatory delay (up to 9 minutes for paroxetine) and orgasm disturbance. In addition to SSRIs, topical anesthetics (e.g., lidocaine-prilocaine spray) can be used to reduce the sensitivity of the penis and thereby decrease sexual stimulation. In addition to medical therapy, behavioral therapy can be offered to patients with significant psychological distress (e.g., lack of self-confidence, impaired life quality) and to those in whom psychogenic factors (e.g., anxiety, depression) play a role in the development of premature ejaculation.

In patients with concomitant erectile dysfunction, phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil, tadalafil) are used first-line because premature ejaculation is often an outcome of erectile dysfunction. Note that this drug class should be used with caution in patients who are treated with alpha-receptor blockers, such as tamsulosin, because of a risk of orthostatic hypotension.

Chlorthalidone is a thiazide diuretic that can cause erectile dysfunction. This patient has premature ejaculation without erectile dysfunction. Discontinuation of chlorthalidone is unlikely to provide any benefit to this patient.

question_text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department (ED) by law enforcement authorities 30 minutes after he sustained a laceration to the left hand in a bar fight. The officer who brought him to the ED says that the patient appears intoxicated and received first aid from paramedics. The patient initially sat on the hospital gurney and mumbled to himself quietly, but when a resident attempts to remove the dressing around his hand, he begins shouting and insists that he be allowed to leave. When the resident attempts to talk to the patient, he stares silently at the resident and clenches his fists. In addition to removing potentially dangerous objects from the patient's vicinity and requesting for the presence of additional personnel close by, which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the resident?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department (ED) by law enforcement authorities 30 minutes after he sustained a laceration to the left hand in a bar fight. The officer who brought him to the ED says that the patient appears intoxicated and received first aid from paramedics. The patient initially sat on the hospital gurney and mumbled to himself quietly, but when a resident attempts to remove the dressing around his hand, he begins shouting and insists that he be allowed to leave. When the resident attempts to talk to the patient, he stares silently at the resident and clenches his fists. In addition to removing potentially dangerous objects from the patient's vicinity and requesting for the presence of additional personnel close by, which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the resident?
hint: This patient's behavior and posture indicates a risk of impending violence. When confronted with an aggressive or violent patient, the health care provider (HCP)'s first priority is to ensure personal safety and attempt to deescalate the situation.
learning_objective: Recognize strategies for ensuring personal safety and deescalating aggressive behavior in patients.

answers.content: Use the additional personnel to set up a four-point restraint on the patient
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, the use of force, such as physical restraints (e.g., a four-point restraint) or chemical restraints, should be a last resort.

answers.content: Stand between the patient and the ED exit and request that the patient take a sedative medication orally
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, the HCP should position themself closer to the exit than the patient to ensure an escape route in case the aggressive behavior escalates. If a chemical restraint is indicated, it is also appropriate for the HCP to request that the patient voluntarily take the calming medication orally before considering use of force (e.g., physical restraints, involuntary sedation). However, the HCP should not block the exit by standing between the patient and the exit, because this action can be perceived as threatening and lead to escalation of the aggressive behavior. Moreover the HCP should attempt verbal deescalation before considering the use of a chemical restraint.

answers.content: Take turns speaking to the patient with another health care provider
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, it is important to have other HCPs nearby to provide assistance in case the aggressive behavior escalates. However, only one HCP should talk to the patient to avoid confusion and further escalation.

answers.content: Step two arm lengths away from the patient and offer the patient food and water
answers.explanation_why:
To ensure personal safety when dealing with an aggressive patient, the HCP should step two arm lengths away and position themselves closer to the exit (so that there is an escape route) without blocking the patient's view or access to the exit. The HCP should then attempt verbal deescalation. Offering comfort measures (e.g., food, water) is an appropriate initial step. During verbal deescalation, only one HCP should talk to the patient; the HCP should remain calm, maintain a neutral expression, respect the patient's personal space, and avoid gestures that can be perceived as threatening (e.g., sudden movement, staring back at the patient, expressing a condescending or commanding attitude). The HCP should acknowledge the patient's feelings, ask what the patient wants, and allow the patient to choose between different acceptable options (e.g., sitting down or lying down); doing so gives the patient a sense of control while also clarifying rules and limits (e.g., informing the patient that violent or abusive behavior will not be accepted). The HCP should listen actively, use short sentences and simple words, seek out points on which they and the patient can agree, and give the patient time to process information and respond.

If the patient continues to remain aggressive despite attempts at verbal deescalation, it is appropriate to ask the patient to voluntarily take a calming medication orally before considering use of force. The use of force (e.g., physical restraints, involuntary sedation) should only be considered if all other measures fail or if the patient is actively violent. Physical restraints and/or involuntary sedation should not be used as punishment and should be removed as soon as feasible.

answers.content: Sit next to the patient and maintain eye contact in silence until the patient calms down
answers.explanation_why: When dealing with an aggressive patient, the HCP should maintain a safe distance to ensure personal safety and attempt to speak to the patient in a calm tone to deescalate the situation. The HCP should avoid maintaining eye contact because it can be perceived as a threatening gesture and lead to escalation of aggressive behavior by the patient.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 43 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have these strange episodes where my left hand is jerking.”
History of Present Illness:

episodes of involuntary left hand jerking for 3 weeks; occur about once every 30 minutes while awake; last 10–60 seconds

episodes of simultaneous throat clearing and eye blinking for the past 4 days

feels a strong urge to perform both sets of actions; relieved afterward; cannot recall any triggering situations
wife says his symptoms have increased in frequency from one episode every other day to multiple episodes per day
has stopped going to the office and now works from home so his colleagues do not notice

Past Medical History:
humeral arthroplasty after motor vehicle collision 1 year ago
Medications:
no medications
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
noncontributory
Psychosocial History:
does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances
Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

37°C
(98.6°F)
80/min
14/min
135/80 mm Hg
98% on RA
175 cm
(5 ft 9 in)
73 kg
(161 lb)
23.6 kg/m^2

Appearance: mildly uncomfortable
Skin: warm, dry, and intact; no rashes, lesions, or bruises; normal skin turgor
HEENT: no bruises, wounds, or scars; PERRLA; ocular movements intact; one 15-second episode of repetitive throat clearing and eye blinking
Neck: no lymphadenopathy or thyromegaly
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation bilaterally; no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender
Extremities: two sudden episodes of repetitive nonrhythmic involuntary movements of the left hand; one episode lasting about 30 seconds, second episode was interrupted by asking the patient to stop

Neurologic: oriented to person, place, and time; cranial nerves II-XII intact; normal muscle strength and tone; reflexes 2+ and symmetric

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

occur about once every 30 minutes while awake; last 10–60 seconds episodes of simultaneous throat clearing and eye blinking for the past 4 days feels a strong urge to perform both sets of actions; relieved afterward; cannot recall any triggering situations wife says his symptoms have increased in frequency from one episode every other day to multiple episodes per day has stopped going to the office and now works from home so his colleagues do not notice Past Medical History: humeral arthroplasty after motor vehicle collision 1 year ago Medications: no medications Vaccinations: up-to-date Allergies: no known drug allergies Family History: noncontributory Psychosocial History: does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 37°C(98.6°F) 80/min 14/min 135/80 mm Hg 98% on RA 175 cm(5 ft 9 in) 73 kg(161 lb) 23.6 kg/m2 Appearance: mildly uncomfortable Skin: warm, dry, and intact; no rashes, lesions, or bruises; normal skin turgor HEENT: no bruises, wounds, or scars; PERRLA; ocular movements intact; one 15-second episode of repetitive throat clearing and eye blinking Neck: no lymphadenopathy or thyromegaly Pulmonary: clear to auscultation bilaterally; no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender Extremities: two sudden episodes of repetitive nonrhythmic involuntary movements of the left hand; one episode lasting about 30 seconds, second episode was interrupted by asking the patient to stop Neurologic: oriented to person, place, and time; cranial nerves II-XII intact; normal muscle strength and tone; reflexes 2+ and symmetric Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with premonitory urges followed by brief episodes of involuntary, repetitive muscle movements that can be consciously suppressed. This combination of findings suggests a tic disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize tic disorder, and choose the most appropriate management for adult-onset tics.

answers.explanation_why: Dopamine-blocking agents such as risperidone can be used to treat severe symptoms that cause functional impairment in tic disorders. However, before any form of treatment can be initiated, this adult patient who presents with a new-onset tic disorder needs to be evaluated for underlying conditions that can cause secondary tics.

Adult-onset tics can be classified as either primary (idiopathic) or secondary to an underlying medical condition or substance use. Primary tics in adults are very rare, and a detailed history often reveals that symptoms are the recurrence of childhood tics. MRI of the brain is indicated in all adults who present with a new onset tic to exclude an underlying secondary cause of tics (e.g., brain lesions involving the basal ganglia, encephalitis).

Additionally, a thorough workup typically includes an evaluation for psychiatric comorbidities, a detailed history of substance use (e.g., cocaine), and targeted testing to exclude other disorders that can cause tics (e.g., copper metabolism studies for Wilson disease, genetic testing for Huntington disease).

A lumbar puncture can be used to assess the cerebrospinal fluid for conditions that can cause tics, including CNS infections (e.g., meningitis) and paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis due to small cell lung cancer). This patient has no signs of such a condition (e.g., nuchal rigidity and fever in meningitis, weight loss in paraneoplasia), and other, less invasive diagnostic steps are indicated first.

Propranolol is used in the treatment of essential tremor, which can affect the hands and/or voice. Symptoms of essential tremor are classically bilateral and worsen with sustained voluntary movement, making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient. Tic disorder, which this patient has, is not typically treated with propranolol.
Reassurance is appropriate for adult-onset tic disorder only after the exclusion of any underlying medical causes and if the tics do not impair the patient's daily functioning.
