question_text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. She reports that for almost a year, he has been episodically “acting out” by stomping his feet and screaming at home. She says that she sometimes scolds him during these episodes in an attempt to correct his behavior, but his tantrums have become worse and more frequent over time. According to his teachers at preschool, he is calm and plays cooperatively. He was born at term and has been healthy since. He can draw a square, hop on one foot, and brush his teeth. He can identify several colors and numbers and occasionally tells stories to his parents. He enjoys being read stories before bedtime, and he sleeps 11 hours every night and 1–2 hours during the day. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 40^th percentile for both height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The mother is worried that his behavior will continue when he starts kindergarten next year and asks if it would be appropriate to gently spank her son to discipline him. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for responding to the boy’s behavior?
content_preview: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. She reports that for almost a year, he has been episodically “acting out” by stomping his feet and screaming at home. She says that she sometimes scolds him during these episodes in an attempt to correct his behavior, but his tantrums have become worse and more frequent over time. According to his teachers at preschool, he is calm and plays cooperatively. He was born at term and has been healthy since. He can draw a square, hop on one foot, and brush his teeth. He can identify several colors and numbers and occasionally tells stories to his parents. He enjoys being read stories before bedtime, and he sleeps 11 hours every night and 1–2 hours during the day. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 40th percentile for both height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The mother is worried that his behavior will continue when he starts kindergarten next year and asks if it would be appropriate to gently spank her son to discipline him. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for responding to the boy’s behavior?
hint: This child's behavior is consistent with temper tantrums, which are a common and developmentally normal behavior in children 2–5 years of age. Parents must respond to temper tantrums with age-appropriate measures.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate response to preschoolers' temper tantrums.

answers.content: Take away the child's favorite toy after he has a tantrum
answers.explanation_why: Taking away the child's favorite toy after he has a tantrum is an example of negative punishment. Although punishment may be effective in older children and adolescents when coupled with rewards for good behavior, it is not effective for decreasing unwanted behavior in preschoolers. Moreover, while punishment may result in a temporary decrease in unwanted behavior, it does not typically lead to behavior extinction.

answers.content: Restrict the child's daytime naps and put him to bed earlier in the evening
answers.explanation_why: Children who get insufficient sleep can become cranky, which can contribute to temper tantrums. This child is getting sufficient sleep for his age (10–13 hours per day including naps). Furthermore, daytime napping is normal until 5–6 years of age and should not be restricted.

answers.content: Ignore the child while he is having a tantrum
answers.explanation_why:
Ignoring the child (e.g., by putting them on time-out) is one of the most effective approaches for a preschooler who is having a temper tantrum. Although ignoring the child may initially result in a temporary increase in the behavior, this approach eventually leads to extinction by eliminating any positive reinforcement of the behavior. If using a time-out, the parent should briefly explain to the child that the time-out is related to their temper tantrum. No other communication (e.g., scolding, teaching) should take place during a time-out. Physical punishment is largely ineffective and strongly discouraged because it can cause physical harm. Some forms of physical punishment are considered child abuse under state and federal laws. Physical punishment can also have deleterious effects on the child's psychosocial development, e.g., by teaching them that violence is an appropriate means of conflict resolution.

While this is a developmentally normal behavior in preschoolers, health care providers should evaluate children with temper tantrums for conditions that can cause or contribute to tantrums (e.g., hearing and/or visual impairment, learning disabilities).

answers.content: Explain to the child why his behavior is socially inappropriate
answers.explanation_why: Explaining to the child why his behavior is socially inappropriate is useful in older children and adolescents. However, this technique has limited effectiveness in preschoolers. Explaining to a preschooler why a behavior is inappropriate may actually reinforce the behavior by giving them attention.

answers.content: Offering the boy chocolate during a tantrum
answers.explanation_why: Offering the child chocolate during a tantrum is an example of positive reinforcement. Although this response might temporarily console the child, it is likely to inadvertently cause an increase in the unwanted behavior in the future. Parents should reward good behavior rather than reinforce unwanted behavior.

question_text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe chest pain that began after he lifted a heavy box 1 hour ago. On several previous visits, the physician has diagnosed him with costochondritis. He also has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications are ramipril and metformin. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the 4^th to 6^th left rib cartilage. The physician diagnoses costochondritis, prescribes ibuprofen, and sends the patient home. Two hours later, the patient is brought to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, dyspnea, and nausea. ECG shows ST-segment elevations in leads V1 through V4. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this medical error?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe chest pain that began after he lifted a heavy box 1 hour ago. On several previous visits, the physician has diagnosed him with costochondritis. He also has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications are ramipril and metformin. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the 4th to 6th left rib cartilage. The physician diagnoses costochondritis, prescribes ibuprofen, and sends the patient home. Two hours later, the patient is brought to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, dyspnea, and nausea. ECG shows ST-segment elevations in leads V1 through V4. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this medical error?
hint: The physician failed to consider alternative diagnoses (e.g., myocardial infarction) for this patient's chest pain.
learning_objective: Recall the concept of premature closure in medical decision-making.

answers.explanation_why: Commission bias is a cognitive bias in which the physician chooses action or intervention when inaction would have resulted in a similar or better outcome (e.g., excessive testing in a low-risk patient). In this scenario, the physician chose inaction (no further testing) over action (performing an ECG). This is an example of omission bias rather than commission bias. There is another term that better describes the main cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario.

Conjunction fallacy is a logical error in which the probability of multiple coinciding events (e.g., diagnoses) is assumed to be higher than the probability of a single event. The physician in this scenario assumed that the patient was more likely to have one condition (costochondritis) than multiple conditions (costochondritis and myocardial infarction), so conjunction fallacy does not apply. The physician made an immediate diagnosis without considering alternative diagnoses. The cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario is best described by a different term.

Zebra retreat bias is a cognitive bias in which a physician is reluctant to consider a rare diagnosis even though there is evidence that supports the diagnosis. Myocardial infarction is a common condition that should be considered in all patients with chest pain and risk factors for cardiovascular disease. The physician in this scenario made an immediate diagnosis (costochondritis) while failing to consider a common alternative diagnosis (myocardial infarction). The cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario is best described by a different term.

Information bias (psychology) is the tendency to seek more information (e.g., in support of a diagnosis) than is necessary or relevant for making a decision. In this scenario, the physician made a diagnosis (costochondritis) without further verification. The cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario is best described by a different term.

Premature closure bias is a cognitive bias in which a physician makes a premature diagnosis without further verification, thereby increasing the risk of diagnostic errors such as misdiagnosis and delayed diagnosis. In this scenario, the physician immediately made a diagnosis (costochondritis) and failed to consider an alternative cause for the patient’s chest pain (myocardial infarction). The physician should have taken the patient’s risk factors for cardiovascular disease (i.e., older age, diabetes mellitus, hypertension) into account and performed further diagnostic testing. An electrocardiogram is indicated for patients > 35 years of age with suspected costochondritis. If the physician had been aware of his cognitive bias, myocardial infarction could have been diagnosed at the office, which may have improved the patient's outcome. Strategies to avoid cognitive biases include education on cognitive errors, diagnostic time-outs, differential diagnosis generators, and checklists.

In many situations, several cognitive errors can occur simultaneously. Omission bias, overconfidence, and availability bias may have also occurred in this scenario.

question_text: In a private conversation, physician A discloses to physician B that he sometimes leaves the hospital during working hours to go to the mall for personal errands. Physician A claims that he is “doing nothing wrong” as he only leaves when there are just a few patients in the ward. He says that “the nurses don't mind” because he "always brings some donuts back for them." When physician B confronts him about the situation, physician A insists that “nothing bad has ever happened” and “the nurses have everything under control.” A few days later, physician B sees physician A returning to the hospital in the middle of a shift with several bags from the shopping mall. Physician A's actions are best described by which of the following terms?
content_preview: In a private conversation, physician A discloses to physician B that he sometimes leaves the hospital during working hours to go to the mall for personal errands. Physician A claims that he is “doing nothing wrong” as he only leaves when there are just a few patients in the ward. He says that “the nurses don't mind” because he "always brings some donuts back for them." When physician B confronts him about the situation, physician A insists that “nothing bad has ever happened” and “the nurses have everything under control.” A few days later, physician B sees physician A returning to the hospital in the middle of a shift with several bags from the shopping mall. Physician A's actions are best described by which of the following terms?
hint: Physician A's behavior violates the ethical principles of nonmaleficence and beneficence.
learning_objective: Recognize the ethical principles violated by physician misconduct.

answers.explanation_why: Medical malpractice occurs when a healthcare provider violates professional standards through negligent conduct or acts of omission, resulting in patient harm. The elements of malpractice (i.e., the 4 Ds) are the duty to properly treat the patient, dereliction of that duty, damage to the patient, and direct cause of damage through medical negligence. Although Physician A neglected the duty to treat his patients, none have been directly damaged. Therefore, he did not commit malpractice and a different term describes his actions.

Physician misconduct is any behavior that goes against the ethical principles of medical practice. In this scenario, physician A leaves the hospital and puts patients at risk through his absence, which violates the principles of nonmaleficence and beneficence. This behavior is never acceptable regardless of whether it results in harm to a patient or incurs legal consequences. Misconduct can also occur outside the established physician-patient relationship and does not always constitute malpractice (e.g., research malfeasance, fraudulent advertising). Other examples of misconduct include bullying, making inappropriate comments and/or sexually harassing colleagues or patients, billing fraud, and receiving gifts from patients or pharmaceutical industry representatives. Colleagues who suspect a physician of misconduct should report their concerns to the state medical board, and, if the misconduct implies any legal liability, to the appropriate legal authorities.

Slip is an unintentional active error in the performance of a task that is caused by a lack of mindful attention (e.g., accidentally pushing the bolus button instead of giving the medication in infusion). Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

A mistake is a failed outcome resulting from an intentional action because of an error in execution and/or planning (e.g., making a misdiagnosis during an emergency and subsequently performing the wrong diagnostic test). Mistakes are more likely to occur while under time pressure, during multitasking and the execution of complex tasks, and when there is a lack of experience. Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

A lapse is an unintentional active error caused by a lack of mindful attention and a fault in memory (e.g., forgetting about a patient's penicillin allergy and prescribing amoxicillin). Physician A's behavior is better described by another term.

question_text:
Patient information
Age: 64 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: hospital
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: evaluation 12 hours after admission for alcohol intoxication
History of Present Illness:

brought to the emergency department by law enforcement authorities after being arrested for driving under the influence of alcohol
blood alcohol concentration at the time of admission was 250 mg/dL

patient is currently not inebriated but reports alcohol cravings
patient does not recall events leading up to the arrest and is not concerned

Past Medical History: 

hyperlipidemia
hospitalized once 3 years ago for alcohol withdrawal symptoms

Medications:
atorvastatin
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
father: history of alcohol use disorder; committed suicide at age 54 years

Psychosocial History: 

does not smoke or use illicit drugs

drinks 4–5 12-oz beers and ½ bottle of wine daily; started drinking as a teenager; unsuccessfully attempted an outpatient rehab program for alcohol use at the age of 45 years

currently undergoing divorce; separated from wife for 2 years because of aggressive behavior
lost his job as a tax consultant 2 months ago because of alcohol use at work

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

36.0°C
(96.8°F)

80/min
19/min
135/83 mm Hg
98%

190 cm
(6 ft 3 in)
95 kg
(209 lb)
26 kg/m^2

Appearance: irate; no acute distress
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation over all lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S_1 and S_2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: soft; mild tenderness to palpation over the right upper quadrant; hepatomegaly
Neurologic: oriented to time, place, and person; no focal neurological deficits

Which of the following is the strongest indicator of the severity of this patient's alcohol use disorder?
content_preview: Patient information Age: 64 years Gender: M, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: hospital History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: evaluation 12 hours after admission for alcohol intoxication History of Present Illness: brought to the emergency department by law enforcement authorities after being arrested for driving under the influence of alcohol blood alcohol concentration at the time of admission was 250 mg/dL patient is currently not inebriated but reports alcohol cravings patient does not recall events leading up to the arrest and is not concerned Past Medical History: hyperlipidemia hospitalized once 3 years ago for alcohol withdrawal symptoms Medications: atorvastatin Allergies: no known drug allergies Family History: father: history of alcohol use disorder; committed suicide at age 54 years Psychosocial History: does not smoke or use illicit drugs drinks 4–5 12-oz beers and ½ bottle of wine daily; started drinking as a teenager; unsuccessfully attempted an outpatient rehab program for alcohol use at the age of 45 years currently undergoing divorce; separated from wife for 2 years because of aggressive behavior lost his job as a tax consultant 2 months ago because of alcohol use at work Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 36.0°C(96.8°F) 80/min 19/min 135/83 mm Hg 98% 190 cm(6 ft 3 in) 95 kg(209 lb) 26 kg/m2 Appearance: irate; no acute distress Pulmonary: clear to auscultation over all lung fields Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops Abdominal: soft; mild tenderness to palpation over the right upper quadrant; hepatomegaly Neurologic: oriented to time, place, and person; no focal neurological deficits Which of the following is the strongest indicator of the severity of this patient's alcohol use disorder?
hint: This patient meets the diagnostic criteria for alcohol use disorder (AUD). The more criteria the patient meets, the more severe the condition.
learning_objective: Recognize the diagnostic criteria for alcohol use disorder and their role in assessing its severity.

answers.content: Age at onset of alcohol use
answers.explanation_why: Alcohol use at a young age increases the risk of developing AUD but is not a diagnostic criterion for AUD nor an indicator of its severity.

Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a clinical diagnosis that is confirmed if two out of 11 DSM-5 criteria for AUD are met within the past 12 months. These criteria are based on the patient's medical and psychosocial history and include continued drinking despite knowing that physical or psychological problems are likely to have resulted from alcohol use, continued drinking despite exacerbation of social or interpersonal problems (e.g., divorce), inability to fulfill work obligations, clinical features of alcohol withdrawal syndrome, persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to reduce drinking, and drinking in physically hazardous situations (e.g., driving). AUD severity is classified as mild, moderate, or severe based on the number of criteria met. This patient meets several diagnostic criteria for AUD. Assessing the severity of AUD is important for the choice of treatment. Psychosocial intervention alone is the preferred treatment for mild AUD, while a combination of pharmacotherapy and psychosocial intervention is recommended for patients with moderate or severe AUD.

answers.content: Family history of alcohol use disorder
answers.explanation_why: Although a positive family history increases the risk of developing AUD, it is neither a diagnostic criterion nor an indicator of its severity.

Blood alcohol levels can confirm recent alcohol use within 12 hours of the last drink but do not indicate regular heavy drinking. Instead, tests like carbohydrate-deficient transferrin levels, phosphatidylethanol levels, and markers of end-organ damage (e.g., abnormal liver chemistries) assess alcohol use severity.

content_preview: Patient Information Age: 56 years Gender: F, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: White, self-identified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: "I feel restless." History of Present Illness: 6-month history of an episodic urge to move her legs while watching TV in the evening 1–2 episodes per week with symptoms that compel her to move her legs or walk for relief continued episodes despite trying acupuncture and stopping coffee no history of insomnia; her husband reports frequent movement while sleeping Past Medical History: diabetic nephropathy with stage 2 chronic kidney disease hypertension type 2 diabetes mellitus Medications: lisinopril metformin dapagliflozin multivitamin Vaccinations: up-to-date Allergies: penicillin Family History: mother died of breast cancer at the age of 70 years father has type 2 diabetes mellitus Psychosocial History: reports increased stress due to ongoing family conflicts for the past 9 months does not drink alcohol, exercises regularly, and eats a well-balanced diet Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 37.0°C(98.6°F) 80/min 16/min 130/80 mm Hg 98% on RA 160 cm(5 ft 3 in) 75 kg(165 lb) 29 kg/m2 Appearance: no acute distress; appears calm Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops Abdominal: soft and non-tender; no masses or organomegaly Neurologic: fully oriented; normal muscle tone; normal gait; no tremors; sensation to light touch and temperature intact; grade 5/5 muscle strength in all extremities Laboratory Findings Blood Hemoglobin 13.8 g/dL Hematocrit 40% Serum Ferritin 110 ng/mL Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL Urea nitrogen 22 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?
hint: While at rest in the evening, the patient has an episodic urge to move her legs. This urge is relieved with leg movement and walking, which is consistent with restless leg syndrome (RLS).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for intermittent restless leg syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Propranolol is the first-line treatment for akathisia, an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic drugs, and can also be used to treat essential tremor and anxiety disorders. Although this patient reports feeling restless and stressed, her symptoms are not consistent with these conditions and are relieved with movement. Moreover, beta blockers can exacerbate the symptoms of RLS.

High-potency opioids like buprenorphine are commonly used in the treatment of chronic pain and for the management of withdrawal in opioid use disorder. Although low-potency opioids (e.g., codeine) can be used in the management of intermittent or refractory RLS, high-potency opioids are not used to treat RLS.

Lamotrigine is a sodium channel-blocking anticonvulsant with mood-stabilizing properties. Mood stabilizers do not have a role in the treatment of RLS. Only anticonvulsants that are alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands (e.g., gabapentin) are used to treat RLS.

Most cases of RLS are idiopathic or familial, but RLS can also occur as a result of iron deficiency, azotemia (e.g., due to diabetic nephropathy), or the use of certain medications (e.g., beta blockers, dopamine antagonists). The initial treatment of RLS consists of supportive care (e.g., sleep hygiene, exercise, avoiding coffee and alcohol) and iron supplementation. Pharmacotherapy is considered if these measures are unsuccessful. Intermittent RLS (i.e., mild symptoms < 2 ×/week) is treated with intermittent carbidopa-levodopa, benzodiazepine (e.g., clonazepam), benzodiazepine receptor antagonist (e.g., temazepam), or low-potency opioid (e.g., codeine, tramadol) therapy. For patients with chronic persistent RLS, the first-line medication is an alpha-2-delta ligand (e.g., gabapentin, pregabalin). Dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole) were previously the first-line medication for chronic persistent RLS. They are now considered second-line treatment because of their associated risks, such as developing impulse control disorders and long-term augmentation, which is a paradoxical worsening of symptoms with increasing doses.

Risperidone is a mixed serotonin-dopamine antagonist used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and Tourette syndrome. Although the patient reports feeling restless and stressed, her symptoms are not consistent with these conditions. In addition, dopamine antagonists can exacerbate the symptoms of RLS.

content_preview: Patient Information Age: 48 years Gender: M, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I don't want to get cancer.” History of Present Illness: wants to quit smoking tomorrow has attempted to quit smoking multiple times but was not successful has not used nicotine replacement therapy before saw an advertisement for nicotine patches and is interested in trying them motivated to quit because a friend of his was recently diagnosed with lung cancer Past Medical History: hypertension Medications: hydrochlorothiazide Allergies: no known drug allergies Family History: father: prostate cancer mother: breast cancer Psychosocial History: has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years does not drink alcohol does not use recreational drugs works as a mathematics professor Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 37.0°C(98.6°F) 80/min 15/min 133/79 mm Hg - 178 cm(5 ft 10 in) 88 kg(194 lb) 28 kg/m2 Appearance: no acute distress Neck: no jugular venous distention Pulmonary: no increased work of breathing; lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs Abdominal: nondistended; soft and nontender Extremities: no edema In addition to nicotine patches, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
hint: Nicotine patch monotherapy reduces withdrawal symptoms but does not alleviate acute cravings in individuals trying to quit smoking.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate adjunct to nicotine patches in the management of smoking cessation.

answers.explanation_why: E-cigarettes can suppress withdrawal symptoms because they contain nicotine. However, e-cigarettes are not a recommended form of NRT as their long-term effects have not been studied.
Although hypnotherapy is sometimes used as an adjunctive therapy for patients who wish to stop smoking, there is insufficient evidence to support its use.

Combined nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) involves the use of a long-acting nicotine receptor agonist (e.g., patch) along with a short-acting nicotine receptor agonist (e.g., lozenge). This combination treats both withdrawal symptoms and acute cravings and is therefore more effective for smoking cessation than using only one form of NRT. Patients using NRT should be followed up closely to assess for efficacy and side effects. First-line pharmacological treatment alternatives to combined NRT include varenicline and bupropion, which also reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms.

Additionally, behavioral interventions (e.g., counseling) should always be offered as part of first-line therapy to help individuals modify their smoking habits.
Although monotherapy with nicotine patches reduces nicotine withdrawal symptoms, it does not relieve acute cravings. Adding another treatment increases the likelihood of treatment success.
Although acupuncture is included in some smoking cessation programs, there is insufficient evidence to support its use.

question_text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, comes to the physician 3 days after a home pregnancy test was positive. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child 4 years ago were uncomplicated. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the last 10 years but refrained from smoking during her first pregnancy. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.1 g/dL and a serum β-hCG of 2,000 mIU/mL. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a gestational sac consistent with a 5-week pregnancy. When asked about her willingness to quit smoking, the patient replies that she is worried that she won't be able to quit because the frequency of her smoking has increased since the birth of her first child. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention to support smoking cessation in this patient?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, comes to the physician 3 days after a home pregnancy test was positive. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child 4 years ago were uncomplicated. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the last 10 years but refrained from smoking during her first pregnancy. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.1 g/dL and a serum β-hCG of 2,000 mIU/mL. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a gestational sac consistent with a 5-week pregnancy. When asked about her willingness to quit smoking, the patient replies that she is worried that she won't be able to quit because the frequency of her smoking has increased since the birth of her first child. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention to support smoking cessation in this patient?
hint: Treatment recommendations for smoking cessation may differ between pregnant and nonpregnant patients.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate initial intervention to support smoking cessation in pregnant patients.

answers.explanation_why: Behavioral counseling is the first-line intervention for smoking cessation in pregnant individuals and includes frequent (e.g., weekly) office visits and/or telephone counseling for behavioral therapy, motivational interviewing, and the provision of self-help materials. Although pharmacotherapy (e.g., nicotine replacement therapy, varenicline, bupropion) is often used in combination with behavioral interventions in nonpregnant individuals, the safety and efficacy of these medications have not been established in pregnant individuals. Therefore, pharmacotherapy is used on an individual basis in pregnant patients who do not respond to behavioral interventions, when the clinician determines that its benefits outweigh its risks (e.g., in heavy tobacco use).

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) with nicotine gum is a first-line treatment for smoking cessation in nonpregnant individuals. Because its effects on the fetus are not entirely known, NRT is not a first-line treatment during pregnancy.

Varenicline is a first-line treatment for smoking cessation in nonpregnant patients. Because its effects on the fetus are not entirely known, varenicline is not a first-line treatment during pregnancy.

answers.content: Use of a transdermal nicotine patch
answers.explanation_why: Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) with transdermal nicotine patches is a first-line treatment for smoking cessation in nonpregnant patients. Because its effects on the fetus are not entirely known, NRT is not a first-line treatment during pregnancy.

Bupropion is a first-line treatment for smoking cessation in nonpregnant patients. Because its effects on the fetus are not entirely known, bupropion is not a first-line treatment for pregnant patients.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. She feels well and has no history of serious illness. She reports that she has been married for 2 years and has argued with her husband a lot during the past 6 months because she suspects that he is cheating on her. She hasn't spoken to her sister in 4 years because her sister “always humiliates me in front of others.” She gets along well with her friends but does not talk to them about her problems because she is afraid that they will gossip about her behind her back. She works as a teacher at an elementary school. She has been monogamous with her husband for the entire marriage except for a sexual relationship with a colleague 13 months ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she has a stable mood and a neutral affect. Her thought process is goal-directed and thought content focuses on possible negative eventualities, but she demonstrates intact reality testing. Her speech is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

She works as a teacher at an elementary school. She has been monogamous with her husband for the entire marriage except for a sexual relationship with a colleague 13 months ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she has a stable mood and a neutral affect. Her thought process is goal-directed and thought content focuses on possible negative eventualities, but she demonstrates intact reality testing. Her speech is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Projection is a defense mechanism often seen in individuals with this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize paranoid personality disorder.

answers.explanation_why:
Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by excessive suspicion and pervasive distrust of others, while psychotic symptoms are absent. Individuals with paranoid personality disorder often present with suspicions of infidelity, unjustified fear that others will use information against them, and disproportionate reactions to perceived attacks. Consequently, individuals with paranoid personality disorder tend to be emotionally isolated and unable to form close interpersonal relationships (See “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table).

Most patients with personality disorders consider their symptoms normal; these egosyntonic behavioral traits lead to significant distress and impaired social functioning. Personality disorders typically begin in early adulthood and remain stable over time. Treatment is challenging and usually includes psychotherapy. Symptomatic treatment may be helpful in patients with comorbid traits (e.g., symptoms of anxiety, psychosis).

Individuals with schizoid personality disorder may be unable to form close interpersonal relationships and find it difficult to trust others. However, schizoid personality disorder typically also manifests with little interest in sexual relationships and a preference for solitary activities, and mental status examination may show flattened affect.

Individuals with avoidant personality disorder refrain from interpersonal contact because of a preoccupation with, and hypersensitivity to, criticism. However, in avoidant personality disorder, the lack of interpersonal contact results from feelings of inadequacy, low self-esteem, and risk avoidance rather than distrust of others.

Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder may be suspicious and distrustful of others and often lack close friends. However, schizotypal personality disorder typically also manifests with eccentric behavior (e.g., bizarre speech) or physical appearance, magical thinking, unusual perceptual experiences (e.g., body illusions), and/or constricted affect, none of which is seen in this patient.

Individuals with borderline personality disorder (BPD) may be suspicious of others, have unstable personal relationships, and fear abandonment. However, this patient's behavior is more severe than that expected in BPD. In addition, the patient does not display the self-damaging behavior and impulsivity that is characteristic of BPD.

Individuals with delusional disorder may have an exaggerated distrust of others and insist that they are being cheated on, conspired against, and/or harassed. However, delusional disorder also manifests with at least one type of delusion (e.g., jealous, erotomanic, grandiose) and associated clinical features. While individuals with delusional disorder may show impaired reality testing and/or abnormalities of thought content regarding the delusional belief, functioning unrelated to the belief is typically normal.

question_text: A 28-year-old transgender man comes to the office for a follow-up visit. He feels well. He has been on testosterone therapy for 8 months; at his last visit 2 months ago, he reported mood swings and moderate acne, which have both improved. He states that he is otherwise happy with the physical changes caused by hormone therapy. He has no history of serious illness. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows mild facial acne and increased hair growth on the jaw, torso, arms, and legs compared to the last visit. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. This patient's pharmacotherapy puts him at greatest risk of which of the following?
content_preview: A 28-year-old transgender man comes to the office for a follow-up visit. He feels well. He has been on testosterone therapy for 8 months; at his last visit 2 months ago, he reported mood swings and moderate acne, which have both improved. He states that he is otherwise happy with the physical changes caused by hormone therapy. He has no history of serious illness. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Physical examination shows mild facial acne and increased hair growth on the jaw, torso, arms, and legs compared to the last visit. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. This patient's pharmacotherapy puts him at greatest risk of which of the following?
hint: Testosterone therapy may cause effects similar to those seen following high-altitude training.
learning_objective: Recall the adverse effects of testosterone therapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Erythrocytosis is one of the most common adverse effects of testosterone therapy. Proposed mechanisms through which testosterone leads to erythrocytosis include increased bone marrow stimulation and increased iron turnover. Because erythrocytosis is associated with thrombotic events, hematocrit should be monitored and kept < 50%. Changes in the application method or dose reductions may help avoid adverse effects. For example, transdermal administration (e.g., gel) is less likely to cause erythrocytosis. Other possible adverse effects of testosterone therapy include acne, hair loss, dyslipidemia, exacerbation of migraines, and localized injection site reactions. Most transgender people taking hormone therapy report an improved quality of life.

Testosterone is also used in athletic performance enhancement, for which erythrocytosis is a desired effect.

images.title: Gender affirming health care - Transgender man fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Feminizing hormone therapy in transgender women may cause reduced sexual desire and function. By contrast, testosterone therapy does not result in a loss of libido. Transgender men taking masculinizing hormone therapy typically report an increase in sexual interest and improved sexual function.

Although mood can be influenced by hormonal changes, there is no association between testosterone therapy and symptoms of depression. Initiation of testosterone therapy in transgender men usually enhances self-perception and social functioning, leading to improved mood.

Testosterone therapy in transgender men is not associated with an increased risk of osteoporosis. Because testosterone strengthens bone tissue via modulation of bone remodeling, bone mineral density typically remains unchanged or increases over the course of therapy. Screening for osteoporosis should be considered in transgender men who have stopped treatment, do not take hormone therapy as directed, or have independent risk factors for bone density loss.

Estrogen, which is typically used as feminizing hormone therapy for transgender women, increases the risk of breast cancer because of its proliferative effect on breast tissue, which can lead to the accumulation of gene mutations. There is no known association between testosterone therapy and the risk of breast cancer. Transgender men who have not had masculinizing chest surgery should undergo the same screening tests for breast cancer recommended for cisgender women. Although there is a low risk of breast cancer in transgender men who have undergone chest surgery, personalized screening should be discussed.

question_text: A 66-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 2-day history of vomiting and abdominal pain that radiates to his back. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medication includes enalapril and tamsulosin. Treatment with intravenous fluids and ketorolac is initiated. One day after admission, the patient becomes restless and insists on leaving the hospital to “run some errands” against the advice of his treating physician. When a resident tries to talk to him, the patient suddenly approaches her and screams, “I need to leave now!” A nearby nurse who heard the screaming calls the rapid response team. The arriving psychiatrist slowly approaches the patient without blocking the exit, introduces herself, and calmly asks why he would like to leave the hospital. The patient begins to shout at the psychiatrist and pulls out his intravenous catheter. The psychiatrist asks the patient to sit down and have a glass of water. The patient does not respond and starts mumbling and banging his head against the wall. The psychiatrist says, “I would also like for you to leave this hospital when it is possible.” The patient abruptly turns and throws one of his slippers at the psychiatrist. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 2-day history of vomiting and abdominal pain that radiates to his back. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medication includes enalapril and tamsulosin. Treatment with intravenous fluids and ketorolac is initiated. One day after admission, the patient becomes restless and insists on leaving the hospital to “run some errands” against the advice of his treating physician. When a resident tries to talk to him, the patient suddenly approaches her and screams, “I need to leave now!” A nearby nurse who heard the screaming calls the rapid response team. The arriving psychiatrist slowly approaches the patient without blocking the exit, introduces herself, and calmly asks why he would like to leave the hospital. The patient begins to shout at the psychiatrist and pulls out his intravenous catheter. The psychiatrist asks the patient to sit down and have a glass of water. The patient does not respond and starts mumbling and banging his head against the wall. The psychiatrist says, “I would also like for you to leave this hospital when it is possible.” The patient abruptly turns and throws one of his slippers at the psychiatrist. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient is agitated and violent and has not responded to verbal and nonverbal deescalation techniques.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in managing an agitated and violent patient not responding to deescalation techniques.

answers.content: Leave the patient alone and reevaluate him after 15 minutes
answers.explanation_why: Leaving this uncooperative patient alone is inappropriate because he poses an imminent threat to himself and others. Staff and patient safety should always be prioritized; therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this point.

Calming medication is indicated for agitated or aggressive patients who pose a danger to themselves or others and do not respond to nonpharmacological measures. The goal of treatment is to relieve the patient's distress while permitting a safe medical and psychiatric evaluation. In uncooperative patients, parenteral administration is required. If necessary, an intramuscular medication can be used initially to calm the patient and facilitate safe intravenous access. Treatment should be based on the suspected cause and severity of symptoms (e.g., an antipsychotic with a short-acting benzodiazepine for severe agitation). If a patient is cooperative, they should be involved in choosing the medication and administration route (oral medication is preferred).

Physical restraint is sometimes necessary as a subsequent measure if calming medication and deescalation techniques have been unsuccessful and patients continue to be a danger to themselves or health care providers.

answers.content: Ask the patient about his feelings
answers.explanation_why: Noncoercive verbal techniques are appropriate for agitated patients who are otherwise cooperative. This patient is violent and has not responded to numerous verbal and nonverbal deescalation techniques, making another step in management more appropriate at this point.

answers.content: Offer the patient an oral sedative
answers.explanation_why: Offering oral sedatives is appropriate for an agitated or aggressive patient who is otherwise cooperative because giving the patient a choice may defuse the situation and prevent further escalation. However, because this patient is uncooperative and poses a danger to himself and his health care providers, another step in management is more appropriate to ensure patient and staff safety.

answers.content: Discharge the patient against medical advice
answers.explanation_why: Because this patient is uncooperative and poses a danger to himself and others, discharge against medical advice is inappropriate.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 24 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I had another seizure today at work.”
History of Present Illness:

patient is accompanied by a colleague who reports that the patient slipped from her chair in the cafeteria and that her arms and legs shook for about 7 minutes with her eyes closed

patient does not recall what happened during the event but could hear her colleagues talking; she says that she felt a bit uneasy before the event
reports no weakness, speech impairment, or confusion after the event
has experienced similar episodes multiple times over the past 2 years and has seen several care providers; neuroimaging and video EEGs have shown no abnormalities

was prescribed levetiracetam therapy 12 months ago; at a visit 2 weeks ago, the dosage of levetiracetam was decreased with the goal of discontinuing the medication in 2 months

Past Medical History:
generalized anxiety disorder
Medications:

sertraline
levetiracetam

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
noncontributory
Psychosocial History:

works as an administrative assistant
lives alone in a one-bedroom apartment after a recent breakup with a long-term partner
does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

37°C
(98.6°F)

70/min
14/min
120/80 mm Hg
98% on RA

165 cm
(5 ft 5 in)
60 kg
(132 lb)
22 kg/m^2

Appearance: calm
Skin: intact, no bruises or lacerations
HEENT: PERRLA; oral mucosa pink and moist; no visible injuries
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender
Neurologic: alert and oriented to person, place, time, and situation; thought process coherent; speech clear and fluent; all cranial nerves intact; normal muscle tone and strength bilaterally; deep tendon reflexes 2+ throughout

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

she says that she felt a bit uneasy before the event reports no weakness, speech impairment, or confusion after the event has experienced similar episodes multiple times over the past 2 years and has seen several care providers; neuroimaging and video EEGs have shown no abnormalities was prescribed levetiracetam therapy 12 months ago; at a visit 2 weeks ago, the dosage of levetiracetam was decreased with the goal of discontinuing the medication in 2 months Past Medical History: generalized anxiety disorder Medications: sertraline levetiracetam Vaccinations: up-to-date Allergies: no known drug allergies Family History: noncontributory Psychosocial History: works as an administrative assistant lives alone in a one-bedroom apartment after a recent breakup with a long-term partner does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use other substances Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 37°C(98.6°F) 70/min 14/min 120/80 mm Hg 98% on RA 165 cm(5 ft 5 in) 60 kg(132 lb) 22 kg/m2 Appearance: calm Skin: intact, no bruises or lacerations HEENT: PERRLA; oral mucosa pink and moist; no visible injuries Pulmonary: clear to auscultation Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender Neurologic: alert and oriented to person, place, time, and situation; thought process coherent; speech clear and fluent; all cranial nerves intact; normal muscle tone and strength bilaterally; deep tendon reflexes 2+ throughout Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient is likely experiencing nonepileptic seizures.
learning_objective: Recognize psychogenic nonepileptic seizure, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Deep brain stimulation is an invasive treatment used primarily for pharmacoresistant epilepsy. It is not indicated for nonepileptic seizures.

Increasing the dose of levetiracetam is appropriate for seizures thought to be caused by rapid taper of the antiepileptic medication. However, because this patient's seizures are nonepileptic, they are not related to the taper of levetiracetam.

Cross-tapering from sertraline to a tricyclic antidepressant (e.g., amitriptyline) can be indicated for treatment-refractory depressive disorders or anxiety disorders. Tricyclic antidepressants are not used to treat nonepileptic seizures.

answers.content: Prescribe alprazolam to be taken at the onset of premonitory symptoms
answers.explanation_why: Short-acting benzodiazepines (e.g., alprazolam) are indicated for the management of acute panic attacks and acute epileptic seizures. While panic attacks can manifest with lightheadedness and derealization, other expected findings of an acute panic attack such as somatic symptoms (e.g., palpitations, tachycardia, sweating) and associated cognitive symptoms (e.g., fear of dying, fear of losing control) are not seen in this patient. Moreover, extensive extremity movements are typically not seen in acute panic attacks. Benzodiazepines are not used to treat nonepileptic seizures.

Lamotrigine is used for seizure prophylaxis in patients with generalized tonic-clonic seizures and for patients who have breakthrough seizures while on levetiracetam monotherapy. However, since this patient's seizures are nonepileptic, adding another antiepileptic drug is not indicated.

Prolonged seizure duration, closed eyes, unimpaired awareness during the event, lack of postictal phase, and absence of injuries indicate psychogenic nonepileptic seizures (PNES) rather than epileptic seizures. PNES resemble epileptic seizures but are psychiatric in origin and do not result in abnormalities on neuroimaging or video EEG. PNES more commonly occur in women than in men. Individuals with PNES often have psychiatric comorbidities, such as depression, anxiety, posttraumatic stress disorder, and/or personality disorders.

Initial management involves explaining the diagnosis to the patient in a supportive and nonjudgmental manner to help them gain insight. The patient should then be referred for psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy) and/or assessment for a potential underlying predisposing psychiatric comorbidity. Antiepileptic drugs are not used in the treatment of PNES.

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-year history of poor performance at school. His mother says the patient has had difficulties with speech from an early age. He often refuses to wear shoes, repetitively flaps his hands, and is easily startled by certain sounds. She says his teacher reports that he mostly plays by himself, which consists of lining up toy trucks. Medical history is remarkable for functional constipation. His only medication is polyethylene glycol as needed. He is at the 60^th percentile for height, the 55^th percentile for weight, and the 88^th percentile for head circumference. He does not respond to the physician's questions but occasionally looks at the objects that the physician points to and uses physical gestures to show interest in objects. Hearing and vision tests show no abnormalities. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
content_preview: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-year history of poor performance at school. His mother says the patient has had difficulties with speech from an early age. He often refuses to wear shoes, repetitively flaps his hands, and is easily startled by certain sounds. She says his teacher reports that he mostly plays by himself, which consists of lining up toy trucks. Medical history is remarkable for functional constipation. His only medication is polyethylene glycol as needed. He is at the 60th percentile for height, the 55th percentile for weight, and the 88th percentile for head circumference. He does not respond to the physician's questions but occasionally looks at the objects that the physician points to and uses physical gestures to show interest in objects. Hearing and vision tests show no abnormalities. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
hint: Impairment in communication and social interaction (e.g., playing alone), restricted patterns of behavior (e.g., narrow interest in lining up toy trucks), and repetitive movements (e.g., hand flapping) are core features of autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
learning_objective: Recognize autism spectrum disorder, and recall its prognostic factors.

answers.explanation_why: Persistent speech impairment by the age of 5–6 years is a major indicator of poor prognosis in children with ASD. Early intervention by speech-language pathologists can promote the development of speech, language, and communication skills to improve overall patient outcomes. Other indicators of poor prognosis in ASD include cognitive impairment, persistent absence of joint attention, a history of seizures or neurological comorbidities, and late treatment initiation.

Hyperreactivity to sensory input is a feature of ASD and can result in behaviors such as avoiding certain clothing (e.g., due to an aversion to specific textures) and startling easily with certain sounds. However, sensory hyperreactivity does not significantly influence the prognosis of individuals with ASD.

Fixated interests, which result in stereotyped activities and behavior patterns, are a core feature of ASD. However, fixated interests can also manifest in mild ASD and do not significantly influence the prognosis.

Joint attention is the ability to intentionally focus on an object with another person by one alerting the other through actions like pointing or eye gazing. In a patient with ASD, the ability to engage in joint attention (e.g., looking at objects that the physician points to) indicates a good prognosis.

Children with ASD may be at higher risk of having difficulties with toilet training, often triggering constipation. However, functional constipation is a common condition in young children and does not significantly influence the prognosis of ASD.
